effectiveness_7_SP: Supply-side policies (limiting oil extraction)--this can be formulated as one of the above types
comments_important_policies_1: I don't quite understand the question. Is it asking how important I think each of these should be, or how important they are empirically. I answered in terms of the former. I think we need an "all hands on deck" approach to policy at this point. Forget about nuance and just do whatever is feasible and verifiably brings down emissions (no offsets, e.g.).
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: I do believe equimarginality and related cost reductions are important if we think the cost-benefit analysis is near break-even (but I don't think it is close). Cost certainty is benefit of carbon taxes. Learning the cost of abatement is an under-appreciated strength of cap-and-trade systems.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Political feasibility: we don't see many effective pricing schemes passed. Cap-and-trade seems especially subject to gaming, over-supply of permits, etc. The Schlenker-Heal result on Hotelling and Pigou also suggests that we are dramatically under-estimating how high the carbon price needs to be.
comments_cp_statements1_1: The last question was hard to answer. It depends, of course, on how the cap-and-trade system is put into place. You can make it very costly for the public if you want to.
further_research: The political science of the issue certainly needs more study. We have seen some moderately effective carbon prices, and we have seen some high-profile efforts fail. More study of why these events occur would be helpful.

Research_interests_1: energy policy, energy transition, energy economics, energy systems planning
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: In general I am a supporter of carbon pricing. However, determining the correct price is always a challenge. From this perspective, I am in favor of cap and trade policies rather than carbon taxes since cap and trade at least secures a level of emissions and the price is an outcome of the market. Therefore, cap and trade is an effective policy to reduce (not eliminate)  uncertainty regarding future emissions levels.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Determining the correct price is a challenge, particularly for carbon taxes type of policies. There is too much uncertainty regarding the choice of a price that can indeed produce a desirable outcome. On the other hand, cap and trade (less uncertainty) are policies that may take long time to create an impact and their implementation, regulation and design (for instance, how allowances are initially allocated?) is always a hard question to answer.
further_research: Defining a correct price, sectoral price versus economy wide taxes, who pays the tax (upstream, downstream), emissions accountability are all issues that must be taken into account.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Transfers of money from rich to poor countries. Emissions cap stimulates process efficiency and carbon capture technologies. Carbon pricing internalizes externalities and can contribute to the reduction of pollution and increase social welfare
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Needs an efficient and reliable system for trading emissions. Needs a global agreement between different nations, with different development goals. Weak (unified) global governance. Little control over the actual emissions of a project or sector (for abatement purposes)
further_research: Methods for determining the price of carbon. Reliable processes for emissions monitoring. Ensure that credits generated from avoided emissions are properly accounted, monitored, and made available for trading in a secure and reliable way. Insert more elements of artificial intelligence and internet of things for emissions monitoring, as well as technologies such as blockchain to give more traceability to the credits (and transactions) generated. Understand the impact of carbon pricing on people's consumption behavior (willingness to pay, etc.). Clearly demonstrate to different sectors and governments the importance of planning for cross-subsidies towards a more circular and greener economy

Particularly in the northern areas of Pakistan the glaciers are melting at an alarming rate while the southern part of the country is facing the problem of extended drought, low precipitation and sea water intrusion. Although, Climate change policy in Pakistan is available however, it is not being implemented in its letter and spirit.

Research_interests_1: energy system analysis, life cycle assessment, energy system economics
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: One of the strengths of carbon taxes is that emitted CO2 emissions during use are paid for. Cap and trade defines the amount of CO2 to be emitted. Both are strong tools, but with downsides which need to be considered further.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Currently CO2 prices are still to low to cover the costs of the emitted CO2 and we don't know the actual price yet (with all the chain reaction global warming could release, the costs might be higher than expected). Also the CO2 tax and cap and trade only consider the use phase not e.g. the production or recycle processes. CO2 taxes also have the potential to let social injustice rise (prices are relatively higher for poorer people) and with that there is the danger of more political division and a growing lack of understanding for the necessity of the measures for climate change mitigation among those groups. With cap and trade, the ability to balance the emissions is only possible as long as the system isn't carbon neutral, which is the goal eventually. Thus, it allows (especially bigger) companies to stay on their current track with buying more certificates.
further_research: Pricing of the whole life cycle not just the use phase, effects on energy poverty and social injustice, effects of carbon border adjustments including how to e.g. tax imported goods (with uncertainty of emitted CO2 during production)

Research_interests_1: global climate governance, carbon markets, just transition, coal phase-out, industry transformation
comments_1: I consider effectiveness extremely important, but my concern is less about short-term emission reductions (as implied in the survey) and more about more about facilitating long-term transformational change. Sometimes these coincide, but certainly not always.
comments_policy_rank_1: Again, effectiveness should be informed by long-term transformational change and not emission reductions alone. It is very difficult if not impossible to assess efficiency without assuming effectiveness. If a policy is not effective, it cannot be efficient! On feasibility, cap-and-trade systems may have relatively lower barriers to implement, but experience has shown that every new trading period opens up renewed political contestation and opportunity to undermine it. The instrument creates problematic politics with relation to its maintenance. Moreover, I am concerned about its "hegemonic ambition". C&T can undermine the politics of other complementary policies , "because every additional policy will undermine the efficiency of the C&T system".
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: For actors that are particularly sensitive to carbon/energy prices, carbon pricing can have important effects on investment and operational decisions.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing (with realistic price levels) have limited effects on areas that are dominated by satisfycing behavior of actors not particularly sensitive to carbon/energy prices. E.g. many energy efficiency measures in households or service industries are already cost-effective and still do not happen. A carbon price will hardly change that. Moreover, a carbon price alone does little to change the direction of the innovation frontier, especially for those areas in which energy prices are not a major cost factor. It may incentivize more marginal innovation/improvements, but hardly any more disruptive technology changes.
comments_cp_statements1_1: While I agree with the general statement about consumer decisions prices vs. env. concerns, I think the statement is too simplistic. In practice, many other factors (fashion, product quality, advertisement etc.) are more important. And in practice, carbon pricing will have a marginal effect on consumer prices to the extent that it won't matter in the vast majority of consumer decisions.
further_research: I would find it really interesting to study the effect of existing carbon pricing schemes on the formulation/adoption/implementation of complementary policy instruments. My hunch is that carbon pricing and its particular political economy may be crowding out other necessary policies.

weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: People don't realize when they get money from carbon tax dividends redistributed (e.g. Canadian provinces or Switzerland). Political feasibility: Some fear the government is grabbing money in the process. Some instrumentalize the "the poor" to oppose the carbon tax policy. Some fear that there is too much redistribution. Some fear some industries (including jobs) might die cause they cause too much carbon, with tax their products become more  expensive until not desirable anymore. Carbon border adjustment gets tricky (e.g. fuel tourism in regions near boarders). Injustice that richer people can still emit more (under c-tax).

comments_1: The difference between right and left, technical solution and degrowth ideologies are quite center to the question
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing have as main advantage to give a monetary value to carbon, accounting for the damages done to the economy of climate change. It participate to the rationalization of the debate around peremptory facts. It talks with the language (cost/benefits, economy) of the natural political opponents of  climate change mitigation (economic liberals, conservatory right), avoiding them to discard the topic based on ideological views.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon tax, blindly applied, penalize the poorest fraction of the population as it is basically a flat tax. It increases the fracture in western countries between rurals/peri-urbans and inhabitants of large cities/metropoles, as the first are totally dependant of their car or need more energy for heating their home. Ignoring this leads to episodes like the yellow jackets in France, or a radicalisation to the far-right of the peri-urbans leading to the rise in power of this political faction that is deeply climatosceptic. Regarding cap-and-trade, I just think that this will just create a market of carbon tax evasion, with no effect on the overall emissions.
comments_cp_statements1_1: a generalised carbon tax seems to me like a parameric VAT, what would lead to an overall inflation. I m not sure how this truly affect the buying capacity/richness of populations, or the tax income of states.
further_research: my field is blue carbon, ie the capacity of some specific coastal ecosystems to sequester carbon for long (>100yr) periods of time. This is used by policymakers to give a value to the hectare of ecosystem, based on carbon amount sequestered per year. At the moment, only biomass and organic carbon burial rate (in eg. mangroves) is considered as CO2/GHG sinks. however, these ecosystems are also sources and sinks of GHG such as methane and nitrous oxide emissions (~30 and ~260 CO2 equivalent), total alkalinity production through rock weathering  or  production (CO2 sinks). These needs more research, definitely.
comments_background_1: Maybe better would be to ask if people are rather pro-degrowth or favorizing technical solutions (geo-engineering for example), what resumes well the right/left difference on the question of CO2 mitigation.

criteria_5_SP: Accuracy of scientific views on climate goals
comments_policy_rank_1: This question is not well designed. Because it's not well understood how to evalue the efficiency of theses mentioned instruments, or for what country? Or for the world as whole? For example the political feasibility of implementing a carbon tax in agriculture maybe high in Russia, but very low in Europe. So for the researcher is a hard task to answer this question properly of weather it (his answer) should be based on theoretical knowledge or on empirical knowledge which is usually country (or region) specific.
comments_important_policies_1: Here I answered only for the country where I am from, for Russia. If I was asked the same question about some European country the answers would be different.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: I think carbon pricing could be a great method for climate mitigation in an ideal world, where you put the carbon price on extreme pollutants, and they reduce their emissions more or less immediately, and after that our planet stops getting warmed. But what if that doesn't work and the climate keeps on getting warmed even after the we implement carbon pricing?
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing should be harmonized with other methods. It's impossible to achieve good carbon pricing policy without technical efficiency of the industry, and without proper rules for estimating carbon spillovers (basically pollutants). Thus a more advanced science is needed. And science is always time and money. If the accuracy of climate science is not well achieved how can we propose such hard and costly economic measures as the price of carbon.
comments_2nd_order_1: Since I mostly work in the field of agricultural economics, I could suppose that in Russia the answer for the question could be - none. For many years Russian agricultural producers where trying to decrease their costs of production to become competitive. And nobody would like to increase their costs by this additional measure such as carbon tax (or carbon price). On the other side of the hand the farmers (and researchers) they are aware of climate change and tackle (or face) these problems almost every year (because the frequency of draughts in Russian agricultural areas increased). That's why I suppose that they already take (or make) climate mitigation (or adaptation) decisions at their own costs now, and they don't need additional tax for that. I can also assume that farmers could be against the carbon tax for other industries because it would automatically rebounce in increasing costs for the inputs, which the farmers buy.
further_research: It's not well understood how the carbon pricing could be implemented for different sectors of economy, or is it just for the energy sector? Even if so (for the energy sector) it is not well understood how the positive economic (welfare) effects will be distributed in the other sectors of economy, and how fast it will happen.

Research_interests_1: energy economics, energy policy, climate policy
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: I think the strength of these two measures is primarily that they are able to provide exact internalization of the negative climate externality of CO2 emissions, and therefore an efficient pathway for emission reductions. Moreover, these instruments can be highly effective. A cap-and-trade instrument provides incredible certainty of achieving a (maximum) certain level of cumulative emissions (neglecting carbon leakage). Also, conforms to the polluter pays principle.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Given uncertainty about the marginal damage of emissions, there is inherent uncertainty regarding the appropriate tax or emissions cap that results in exact internalization of the negative externality. However, if one takes emissions targets as given, this worry vanishes with a cap-and-trade instrument since such an instrument will guarantee an efficient pathway for achieving the emissions target. At least, when all emissions are embodied in the program. Which leads to another weakness: carbon leakage. If other regions do not implement carbon pricing, production may move towards such regions given that their competitiveness vs. the region with carbon pricing improves. Another weakness is that carbon pricing directly confronts society with the costs of reducing emissions. Carbon pricing increases final prices, such that the effects are directly visible to consumers. With other instruments, such as subsidies, the costs may be much more implicit (e.g. through reduced public spending on other goods), even though those costs to those same consumers may be much greater. I actually do not regard this final point as a weakness of carbon pricing, but observe that society (politicians running for re-election probably primarily) views this as an undesirable aspect of carbon pricing.
further_research: My awareness of the most recent advances is probably below-average. Disregarding that, I think that the following topics may be relevant: - design of carbon pricing at borders. - public acceptance of carbon pricing vs. other instruments. - (political) motivation for implementing policy instruments. - ...

comments_1: Effectiveness is a function (amongst others) of feasibility which is a function (amongst others) of equity.
comments_policy_rank_1: For cap and trade: there is a price risk. Low prices are ineffective but feasible, high prices are effective but very often politically not feasible. A similar argument applies for the tax, but at least, there is less "low-price-risk" with the tax compared to cap-and-trade.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: The efficiency that these instruments provide when being allowed to work in price ranges that are effective.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The required price levels to be effective are often politically not feasible. Thus, policy makers divert to instruments which are less efficient but where costs are less prevalent. Thus, carbon pricing is hardly allowed to do the good it could do.
comments_cp_statements1_1: The innovation impact of carbon pricing depends on long term credibility.  The innovation incentive fails without sufficiently credible commitment to long term carbon pricing on the policy side.
further_research: In my impression, even many economists do not understand that in a stochastic world, the pricing of emission allowances is more akin to financial option pricing with the future stringency of the cap as the underlying rather than a simple equation of the type "p=mac". Many textbooks and simulation models entirely focus on the latter.

Research_interests_1: carbon taxes, emissions trading, offsets, climate finance
comments_1: Interaction with other mitigation and non-mitigation policies
comments_policy_rank_1: Specific policies can be designed to improve performance with respect to the criteria. Regulations can include tradable credits to improve efficiency. A carbon tax can use revenue to address equity and improve political feasibility. etc.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: The principal advantage of carbon pricing is that it promotes implementation of the low cost emission reductions across the regulated sources; specifically those whose cost per tCO2e reduced is lower than the tax rate or allowance price. In the absence of technological or socio-economic changes or other policies that reduce mitigation costs, further emission reductions require tax rate increase or ETS cap reductions over time. In this way carbon pricing creates an implicit strategy of moving from low to high cost mitigation measures. A second advantage is that taxes and auctioned allowances generate revenue for the government.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The corresponding limitations of carbon pricing instruments are that they: o	Do not encourage adoption of higher cost (cost per tCO2e higher than the tax or allowance price) mitigation actions/technologies such as adoption of renewable energy technologies and measures to abate industrial process emissions. o	Have limited impact on adoption of mitigation measures in situations where decisions are not sensitive to price incentives such as recycling, household energy efficiency, transportation, urban planning, choice of infrastructure and scope of electricity grids. o	Have limited impact on long-term investments such as R&D and new facilities.
comments_cp_statements1_1: The questions implicitly presume that carbon pricing is the only policy. In practice most emissions will be directly or indirectly affected by multiple mitigation and non-mitigation policies. While theoretical literature favours international, ideally global, policy harmonization experience for carbon pricing and all other policies reveals this does not happen in practice.
comments_2nd_order_1: Carbon pricing evokes strong views with advocates suggesting that it should be a jurisdiction's main mitigation policy and critics claiming that it is ineffective. As noted above carbon pricing has both strengths and weaknesses.
further_research: Almost no government that levies a carbon tax regularly reports the taxed emissions (all ETSs report actual emissions) so it is very difficult to track the environmental impact of carbon taxes.  Researchers that try have to use other sources of emissions data that do not match the scope of the tax or proxy data such as petrol sales.

Research_interests_1: environment & subjective well-being; environmental valuation; environmental behavior
comments_1: Over the past three decades I have come to think that efficiency should not be overrated. Behavioral economics has taught us that people are willing to forego efficiency in the interest of equity, and the latter is key to support/opposition of climate policy. Maximizing efficiency - in terms of GDP - contributes little to (subjective) well-being in rich countries.
equity_7_SP: Redistributing tax revenues to low income households
feasible_7_SP: Overcoming the division wrt climate policy between ideological camps.
important_policies_7_SP: Spuring a "spirit of competition" with respect to relevant behaviors (e.g. informing people on how much energy they use relative to others).
comments_important_policies_1: All of the above refers to the demand side (for carbon based fuels). These measures must be accompanied by supply-side measures, e.g. investments in public transport and energy infrastructures).
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: The strength of carbon pricing is efficiency, combined with the possibility to avoid undesired distributional consequences by appropriately redistributing the revenues. The latter is indispensible for public acceptance, and it must take a highly salient form, e.g. a cheque sent at the beginning of each year.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Acceptance of a carbon tax may be low unless accompanied by highly salient reimbursement measures. Cap and trade may fare somewhat better than a tax because permit prices arising in markets may not be viewed as state interference to the degree that a tax is.
comments_cp_statements1_1: I am not happy with the recent tendency of subsuming taxes and cap&trade under the header "carbon pricing". They are different in terms of effectiveness and, possibly, resistence of the public (as mentioned above). Plus: the tax needs to be adjusted to the drop in the prices of coal, oil and gas in response to reduced demand. Cap&trade accommodates such energy price changes automatically.
further_research: I have stated above a couple of conjectures about differences between the tax and cap&trade in terms of behavioral responses and public acceptance. I would like to see such conjectures to be tested empirically.
final_comments_cp_1: It would be interesting to ask laypersons the same or similar questions and to analyze the responses wrt income (personal and national) and education level as well as geographically. This would shed light on the feasibility/acceptance issue.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Create strong demand-side incentives for decarbonization whenever alternative consumer choices are fully developed.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: 1. For phasing-out fossil fuel use I would say supply-side instruments are to be preferred in a first line to demand-side. The high profit margins in fossil fuel industry are such strong drivers for putting fuels on the markets.  Supply-side instruments would directly target the industry e.g., strict control of methane emissions, direct subsidies to renewable energy and infrastructure investments. 2. May also be easier to rally public support for supply-side instruments. Although they are likely to increase costs and some be transferred to market prices, it's clearer to consumers why costs have increased if they can be linked to e.g., direct methane regulations. 3. From an equity point of view, it does not seem reasonable to drive decarbonization primarily via consumer choices. We know that such instruments can hit bluntly on different groups (e.g., long-distance commuters as in the case of the yellow vests). Better then to focus on supply-side and e.g., extend public transport infrastructure, upgrade railway systems etc, making these attractive choices before you introduce taxes and higher costs for carbon-intensive choices when consumers do not have the choices. Bottom line: Drive decarbonization first through supply-side regulations and investments and when choices have been fully developed then it's time for demand-side instruments like carbon tax or cap-and-trade to make consumers move to the better choices.
comments_cp_statements1_1: Commenting on the last j) statement: if you want carbon prices to fix the climate problem then you cannot use it as a tax base. You can't have both!
further_research: We need sector-level studies to better understand what supply-side measures must first be put in place to unlock the good consumer choices. Only then does it make good sense with demand-side measures both from an equity and feasibility point of view.

Research_interests_1: energy policy, technology policy, policy change, policy feedback
comments_policy_rank_1: It always depends on how specific instruments are designed! Not sure the sort of categorical assessments you're after here is helpful. There's a difference between a badly designed subsidy and a well-designed one; that holds for every instrument.
comments_important_policies_1: Again: it depends on the design & not the instrument type per se/as such...
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: I don't see any particular strength.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing as 'one-shot solution' is very problematic because if everyone buys into the narrative of this being the 'first-best' option the result is most likely the adoption of badly designed carbon pricing all around. Everything else, (well-designed) instruments and tools that have a specific function are then neglected.
further_research: We generally lack knowledge of policy AND more specific design preferences of (relevant) actors. Carbon pricing is generally associated with a belief in market-based solutions/logics. We don't know how carbon pricing being discussed prominently influences those actors that are normally not associated with market-based logics.
final_comments_cp_1: To be frank, I think you have missed an opportunity here: It's not about instrument type A vs B - it's about good design!

Research_interests_1: bioeconomy, sustainable welfare, eco-social policy, social and environmental attitudes
criteria_5_SP: is not damagin to quality of life, ecology
comments_1: 1. It should be distiguished between economic costs and welfare sacrifices (criteria of efficiency): Welfare can be provided at lower costs than today and there are a lot of concepts how to achieve welfare beyond/without growth, e.g. through universal basic services (public infrastructure) aiming to provide a social floor and good life for all :). 2. An additional criteria may be that the climate policy may not undermine efforts to stay within planetary ecological boundaries in other areas, e.g. increased land use for plant-based fuels etc.
effectiveness_7_SP: banning and limiting activities leading to emissions
comments_policy_rank_1: Cap & trade: effectivness should be high, but experience with European ETS shows: it all depends how it is implemented. The cap needs to be a strict cap, no free or cheaper certificates, the amount must be stricly limited to what ecological boundaries. Direct regulation: technical standards are a quite soft example for regulation, what about bans and laws?
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: it seems very effective in our market economies, companies will seek cheaper solutions as alternatives to emission-intensive activities; it is easily scalable; effects can be calculated; the cap aspect of cap-and-trade isn't actually a pricing mechanism but setting a limit by law - everything what takes place below this limit is then subject to market mechanisms..
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: socially unjust if the poor are burdened disproportionally, prizing mechanism are not transformative they are adapted to and support our current damaging, exploitative capitalist economy, capital accumulation, monopolization etc. probably cannot be avoided, there may be more social and psychological unintended side effects: very expensive goods (and Co2 emissions are treated as goods if they get a prize) become attractive as distinctive features.
further_research: Public knowledge of carbon prizes: Do you know how much one ton of Co2 costs and who has to pay it?
final_comments_cp_1: Good luck with the project! Looking forward to read about the results.

comments_1: To state the obvious, maybe, effectiveness is a function of the benchmark chosen (e.g. one's own target, somebody else's target/expectation, an aspirational target, or a baseline).  Depending on the benchmark chosen, the assessed level of effectiveness is likely to vary. comments_policy_rank_1: Feasibility depends on the jurisdiction, e.g. direct regulation can be feasible in one country/state/province/etc and not in another.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon tax and cap-and-trade are two different policies, with different strengths and weaknesses. Carbon tax: simple to understand, easy to control by governments, possible to redistribute the proceeds to avoid regressive effects. Cap-and-trade: Efficient and effective in theory, little opposition from oil companies
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon tax: Ineffective at a low level (under 50$/tonne, probably more), push back from oil industry and allied governments (federal and/or state/provincial). Cap-and-trade: Ineffective, does not work as per economic theory, no governmental control, easy to lobby for more allowances, extreme complexity of the market (including assumption that emissions are the same everywhere), displacement of environmental risk from climate to other projects (e.g. dams that destroy lands under use, often Indigenous land),  high risk of displacing mitigation as carbon dioxyde removal/negative emissions/solar geoengineering projects are included in carbon markets.
comments_cp_statements1_1: As to generating revenue through carbon pricing, the schemes that are most effective at getting popular support redistribute the proceeds so as to eliminate the regressive effet of taxation. Carbon pricing is one, simple, instrument among many others, they need to ne used in conjunction. It's not about choosing between regulation and pricing, we need a hugh price and strong state regulation.
further_research: We know enough, what is needed is action. The knowledge gap is how to close down oil & gas companies rapidly.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: easy to understand
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: to be effective, high price i required. does not ensure fairness - needs to be accompanied by other measures to be socially acceptable.

further_research: Not my field of research. I guess How on earth countries would ever agree on a high enough carbon price (in a timely fashion) is an unanswered question.

comments_policy_rank_1: Answers to e.g. carbon tax are highly conditional on permit allocation / use of revenues. Also important that what should be evaluated are policy packages and sequencing of particular policies (first adoption subsidies, then carbon taxes, say).
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Efficiency. In particular, leveraging of decentralised information across numerous market participants. Also that pricing policies will deter rebound effects.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Pricing instruments rely heavily on credibility of the policy path a decade or two out in terms of shifting investment from dirty to clean. If no credibility, investment will not be redirected and policy will have to be revised (made less ambitious) accordingly. They will also have immediate distributional impacts, some of which will be difficult to offset by transfer / 'carbon dividend' payments, and these will fuel political resistance.
further_research: Distributional impacts, political feasibility.
comments_background_1: 'Left'/'right' is a bit dated as a political division.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: it will certainly accelerate the transition if implemented, but other than that it is difficult to pinpoint a precise number or any other quantitative measure for that matter.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: It may distort markets. It will likely be regressive, since energy markets are not transparent and efficient, and it is finally consumers and the general public who will pay for that - not the main responsibles for the emissions. There are much better ways to accelerate the transition, namely direct support to niche clean technologies, as the PV experience has proved overwhelmingly.
comments_cp_statements1_1: My answer to question j) is positive, but I must strongly point out that there are much better and equitable ways of generating public revenues - this is not the place to start a discussion on the topic but I think that the altenatives are rather obvious and well-known.
further_research: I do think that carbon pricing is the wrong approach to climate change. At most it can play a complementary role, and therefore, I do not see the point in researching questions that are well known, like the oligopolistic structure of energy markets which is at the root of the problem. Perhaps a more transparent and democratic system would facilitate true competition, in which case a carbon tax might make somewhat more sense. But then, research should be addressed to ways of democratising energy markets.
comments_background_1: I do not think that 'left to right' is a proper way of assessing political opinions, unless what is meant is the voting pattern, according to existing political parties. Being that I am a Spanish citizen living in Spain, and looking back into history, I would rather consider myself in the tradition of 'enlightenment', broadly speaking

comments_1: In order to shape  effective policy instruments the institutional structure of the public administration should be taken into account
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: cap and trade: provides efficiency and does achieve a stipulated standard (emission ceiling). carbon tax:  allows to substitute income taxation to a certain degree.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: cap and trade: institutionally much to complicated. needs to be supplemented by other policies for sectors not suitable for cap and trade; Is bad for competition because the legally enforced participation is associated with relatively high fixed costs. Without a high institutional quality ( Tax authorities, functioning trading platforms) not feasible
further_research: Conventional policy analyses always examine policy instruments with regard to their guiding effect on market participants (consumers, producers). As far as I know, the functioning of state authorities in the implementation of climate policy is only studied in political science. However, the state implementation of climate policy measures also depends on the motivational configurations of the implementing authorities (information procurement, digitalization, bureaucratic effort and much more). State authorities are also participants in the policy game. There is no neutral and effective "Archimedean" Stackelberg leader that chooses the right policy instruments at the proper level.
final_comments_cp_1: I hope you will find results that urges the political arena to act. Good luck!

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Efficiency. More precisely its ability to trigger adoption of low cost emissions reduction options in the presence of other (e.g., standards-based) policies. In addition, in the case of a cap-and-trade system, it places a cap on the quantity of emissions, which makes it the instrument of choice to align emissions pathways with chosen carbon budgets. Revenue recycling: unlike other policies, carbon pricing raises revenue which can be earmarked for specific expenditures (e.g., compensation of disproportionately affected constituencies).
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Low political acceptability
further_research: Design of effective revenue recycling mechanisms targeting most vulnerable consumers - especially in sectors that might be covered by carbon pricing in the future (e.g., road transport and heating fuels).
final_comments_cp_1: Giving answers to the questions about GDP growth is a bit difficult without a clear definition of GDP. I mean I've answered them assuming the mainstream definition of GDP but we could think of a world where GDP is defined differently than it is today.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: cap-and-trade - economically efficient in theory. carbon tax - generate revenue to support transition to lower emissions economy while sending price signals.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: cap and trade: ideologically driven - when the problem is market failure, the solution is probably not a new market. Blunt instrument ignores multiple well-being objectives; susceptible to gaming; lacks strategic oversight (e.g. need to manage the transition to higher-cost emission reductions, not just wait until low-cost options are used up); artificial market with high operating costs and subject to extensive government interference - might as well cut the market ideology and use taxes and regulation.  Equity issues not addressed. Carbon tax: subject to lobbying, inefficiency; red flag to voters; revenue lost into government's consolidated fund.

further_research: None - or perhaps one final study on the true global cost in time and money of designing, implementing, maintaining and analysing a carbon pricing system while the problem it is supposed to be solving gets worse.  More attention in research = "Angels dancing on the head of a pin".

Research_interests_1: energy policy, climate policy, electricity markets
criteria_5_SP: cost-effectiveness, i.e. achieving benefits that exceed costs
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: carbon pricing can be highly efficient (i.e., cost per tonne of emissions reduced). It is also an excellent revenue raising mechanism (supposing permits are auctioned under Cap and Trade) that can be used to achieve other societal objectives (e.g., lowering distortionary taxes or offsetting the distributional consequences).
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: It is often politically unpalatable. The tax revenue (or permit value), which typically exceeds the economic cost of reducing emissions (by an order of magnitude in some cases), is subject to rent-seeking. Trade exposure can undermine environmental and cost-effectiveness if output shifts to unregulated firms.
further_research: The effects on emissions are not well documented. The effects on innovation and technology diffusion are not well documented. The incidence and distributional consequences are not well documented. The effects on industrial organization (i.e., competition between firms) are not well documented.

further_research: The problem I encounter in my research is that presenting anything with the word "tax" in it is likely to cause backlash, particularly among more conservative participants, and particularly in political contexts where the issues has been highly politicised. So if carbon tax is presented more as a pricing scheme, it might elicit different responses, but I would imagine that more work is needed here. Nonetheless, opponents of carbon pricing will usually refer to it as a tax because they know it advantages them politically to do so.

Research_interests_1: behavioural change, lower carbon lifestyles, education for sustainability, climate change communication
comments_policy_rank_1: I've said don't know for all the 'equity' questions as it's not clear what you're asking about. E.g., a carbon tax with no lunp-sum recycling of the revenues would score 'low' for equity, but *with* lump sum recycling would be higher. A cap-and-trade scheme for individuals (personal carbon allowances) scores higher for equity than an upstream scheme like the EU ETS where the costs get passed down to the consumer. I also wasn't really clear about the 'efficiency' question - information provision is low cost so low welfare sacrifice, but since it achieves very little it's not really efficient because the costs are potentially high compared to what is actually achieved. But again, it depends what kind of information. Problem-based information is fairly useless, but use of descriptive and injunctive normative feedback on energy bills can achieve reductions. The Qs are all a bit too general to be meaningful.
comments_important_policies_1: See previous comments about Qs being too general to be able to respond, not clear enough what I'm comparing with what. Overall I'd say it's important to do everything that can achieve anything, though it would make sense to choose between cap-and-trade and C tax, and I would only want to see the latter with lunp sum recycling to prevent it being regressive.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Depends on what kind of pricing. Cap-and-trade is more equitable than a C tax and (in theory) provides a more definite cap on emissions. So I can't compare 'C pricing' to other instruments since C pricing is not one thing. And again, depends how it's done. If visible to consumers, C pricing encourages C literacy, which might be useful, but C taxes often hidden. And in theory C pricing is more efficient than regulation.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: C tax, unlike cap-and-trade, allows richest to keep buying their way out of restrictions pretty much ad infinitum, not the same as cap-and-trade (in theory, reality is different). So can't compare with other instruments simply. I guess one could say that C pricing doesn't restrict people as much as regulation, which can be a weakness.
comments_cp_statements1_1: My response to some of these is "depends" e.g. statement d: agree if C price is low, may not be true if C price is very high. Other statement I don't have the expertise for an opinion.
further_research: Research on public opinion re personal carbon allowances compared to C tax is old and largely UK-based - I'd be interested in more on that

comments_1: When discussing equity in climate policy it is important to remember that any "unfairness" happening within current generation has to be considered along with the unfairness towards the multitude of future generations if climate change is not mitigated.
comments_policy_rank_1: It is really hard to generalize. In Nordic countries, all of these policies already exist, so they are feasible there. It is a completely different question if they are feasible in, say,  Brazil or globally.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: The price signals the strength of the incentives to avoid emissions. The emissions can then be avoided through whichever action the emitter finds best, whether it be reduced activity, changing inputs or changing technology. This means that emissions will be reduced efficiently. It also gives incentives to innovate, as the carbon price (current and expected in the future) feeds into the business calculation of those who develop emission-reducing technologies.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Without redistribution schemes, carbon prices may be regressive. If the net effect of the scheme is regressive, it may hinder political feasibility.
comments_cp_statements1_1: Regarding question b and d: It depends on how high the carbon price is.
comments_2nd_order_1: This includes pricing carbon on a g/km basis in the vehicle purchase tax.
further_research: What are the key factors for making carbon pricing politically feasible? How can can governments commit to a relatively predictable carbon-price trajectory rule, so that people can form reasonable expectations about future carbon prices?
comments_background_1: Where I place myself depends on the policy question, so my placement could go radically in different directions on different policies, bu "on average" I guess I am fairly center-left.
final_comments_cp_1: Mostly well-made survey. Some ambiguous questions.

Research_interests_1: Ornithology, climate and land-use change impacts, bird conservation, indicators, population and community ecology
comments_1: Environmental aspects should be considered regarding costs of climate policy because climate adaptation measures like eg. bioenergy crop production have been shown to have adverse effects on biodiversity. Such effects should be minimised.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: cap-and-trade can help to. - reduce overall ghg emissions to a predefined level. - collect money to subsidize transformations towards carbon-free economies. -  stimulate research and investments in innovations. Cap-and-trade could thus complement other instruments of climate policy and, to be effective, should underlie strict regulation to avoid misuse.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Cap-and-trade could be misused to. - create unequal economic benefits for some countries without effectively causing reduction of ghg emissions. Cap-and-trade can be unambitious if governments give out certificates for free (e.g. to subsidize national high emission industries) or allow that profits can be used to counteract innovations.
further_research: Undesirable effects of carbon pricing which might arise due to incoherent implementation, protectionism or green-washing (e.g. biofuels) should be investigated and used to improve cap-and-trade so that it does neither create social inequality nor harm the environment/biodiversity.

comments_policy_rank_1: Results and evaluation are contingent to "how" each option is implemented, not only "what" is implemented.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Taxes are easier to implement in many sectors of the economy and can be designed to be non-regressive. Ideal scenario: universal carbon tax; marginal reductions are achieved;, revenue is invested in required infrastructure/projects to reduce emissions further; and taxpayers have incentives to deduct the tax via the purchase of carbon removal offsets to reach carbon neutrality.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Taxes can be used only to increase public revenue and not for reinvesting in the transformations required to reduce emissions. Both aim to reduce slightly small percentages of emissions (marginal reductions), while the bulk are still emitted, payers of tax/permit might in fact have "the right" to pollute, and may neglect actually (at least) compensate/neutralise residual emissions. Little incentives for international carbon trading (cap and trade) as each country needs to comply their own targets (environmental accountability risk).
further_research: The fact that in many countries the informal economy does not pay taxes, the question is how can they be integrated into it?
final_comments_cp_1: Thank you for the invitation.

Research_interests_1: carbon trading, carbon offsetting, climate finance, political economy of climate change mitigation
criteria_5_SP: Fairness, i.e., historical responsibility and respective capabilities
comments_1: On efficiency, I'm cautious as the efficiency argument can lead to policy that is ineffective (free allowances in emissions trading schemes, etc.)
comments_policy_rank_1: Carbon taxes and cap-and-trade: the question seems to imply that the objective is achieved and it's a question of cost. I'd argue that the objective often isn't achieved given the political design of pricing instruments and the fact that prices are typically too low (by design), while schemes contain copious exemptions and loopholes.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: If done properly, a carbon tax can help to reflect the cost of emitting and thus lower emissions.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Pricing is highly politicized, posing barriers. This often results in systems that are too weak with too many exemptions and loopholes, particularly for cap-and-trade. Caps are set too high, allowances are distributed for free to heavy emitters (shielding them from the cost), and offsetting is problematic. Cap-and-trade doesn't require reductions at the source in line with the science. Distributional fairness issues.
further_research: The significant complexity leads to highly technical/managerial mechanisms and schemes that far too many are unable to understand. This obscures the extent to which they are designed in ways that undermine their effectiveness.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: A carbon tax is straightforward.  Both internalize the fundamental externality.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: A carbon tax is a tax, which people don't like.  Cap-and-trade is overly complicated.  Both are regressive in their distributional effects.
further_research: None come to mind.

comments_1: feasibility is lower as good leadership can make up the difference
effectiveness_7_SP: personal carbon allowance. Also forgt GDP as measure of success switch to wellbeing or happy planet index
important_policies_7_SP: personal carbon allowance and measure success not by GDP but a wellbeing/happy planet index
comments_important_policies_1: a personal carbon allowance drives innovation and sustainable production and consumption from the bottom up. It would be the most effective instrument as as equitable as you'd like to make it - a truly egalitarian version would be more like rationing, if you allow trading of excess carbon then it is more libertarian and less egalitarian but still effective if level set appropriately
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Policies like the EU carbon border tax will be effective in sustainable sourcing. I favor a personal carbon allowance or carbon credit card as proposed by David Miliband, Centre for Sustainable Energy and DEFRA in 2007 - it is even more feasible now as it is easier to calculate carbon footprint of more goods and services. Miliband thought that everyone could have a carbon credit card – and every transaction, journey and purchase would require the credit card to be swiped, and more or less would come off depending on the carbon footprint of your purchase. If you ran out of credit, and needed more, you could purchase off of someone who still had a lot of carbon on their credit card. This idea is an alternative to green taxation. Although green taxes allow more individual freedom, they make environmentally harmful behavior the privilege of the rich, which isn’t fair. A carbon credit card is more like a kind of rationing as everyone has the same carbon allowance which is fairer, but there is still some room to manoeuvre if you allow unspent carbon to be sold to those who need more than they have. Hence when others have run out of carbon, they can buy some of the leftover carbon from those who aren’t using as much.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Not sure cap and trade is enough to STOP fossil fuel extraction and use. Carbon taxation lets rich people off their duty to limit green house gas emissions
comments_cp_statements1_1: Carbon pricing will be effective but could be regressive, so element of a set carbon budget/allowance or ration is more egalitarian.
further_research: It is time to revisit the ideas around personal carbon allowances that are a great compromise between rationing/taxation and would be extremely effective or driving innovation from the bottom up and would be more egalitarian than carbon taxation.
comments_background_1: I'm not sure left/right has much meaning these days - its more progressive vs regressive

Research_interests_1: Agent-Based Modelling, Energy Systems, Energy Transition, Energy Policy, Social Simulation
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: I have long history of research on the topic that shows substantial differences *within* the group of pricing instruments. Strengths include monetary price signal that alters the investment decision, it can be implemented across sectors, across countries and lets the market find out where the cheapest abatement options can be realized. The carbon tax outperforms a cap and trade system, both on effectiveness and efficiency, my research shows. The income generated by tax (or auctions) can be spent on other greening measures, for instance for sectors that are not included in the carbon price.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Global carbon price is hard to realize. Cap and trade provides a cloudy signal, simply because the price can vary. It can only influence large investments if the the perceived risk of lower prices in the future is absent. The carbon tax doesn't have that risk (as long as the guarantee of the tax staying is credible).
comments_2nd_order_1: My background is systems engineering, it was not included as a field. This is multidisciplinary, so it includes lots of things.
further_research: how to include more sectors. how to combine it to other measures. how to adequately account for 'negative emissions'  (which may not be negative at all).

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: It gives incentives to the industry sector to limit their emissions while keeping production costs down. It works pretty well in developed countries due to the presence of an advanced system of control supported by law, public green conscience, and advocacy groups.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: It might now work well in developing countries due to the weak law enforcement and other control mechanisms. In addition, it has a loophole that could be exploited by multinational companies operating in the developing countries, which have weak law enforcement and cheap labour. The practices of those companies might lower the emissions of their countries of origin (mostly developed countries) while increasing the national emissions of the developing countries where they operate and possibly create other types of environmental problems in developing countries.
further_research: As I indicated earlier, carbon pricing is vulnerable to abuse my multinational companies operating in developing countries. Therefore, research on various (domestic and international) mechanisms to curb this possible misuse is worth doing.

further_research: Industrial Ecology uses the perspective of physical stock dynamics to assess current and expected GHG emissions related to infrastructure, buildings, products, etc. The realization that their production/deployment contribute to decent living standards (i.e. the SDGs) as well as to carbon emissions leads me to believe there is a certain level of inevitability to exhausting a significant portion (if not all) of the remaining carbon budget to fulfill basic human needs. Therefore, I think that a raw/myopic implementation of carbon pricing could conflict with the fulfillment of basic needs, or a more regulated carbon pricing scheme (in conjunction with sustainable development policies) may only have a limited effect in terms of GHG emission reductions.

Research_interests_1: energy system transformation, climate neutrality in heavy industry
comments_policy_rank_1: Of course, the rating for many of these instruments would depend very much on their exact design, so I tried to rate in regard to the "average" design of each instrument.
comments_important_policies_1: I think it is "extremely important" to have either a carbon tax or a cap-and-trade mechanism. But since I generally favor the former, I rated cap-and-trade only "very important".
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing is a relatively simply instrument (especially a carbon tax) that is able to cover all fossil fuel emissions, or - depending on the scope - at least a large part of these emissions. So it can have a positive impact on reducing emissions in all/many sectors. It is also a relatively efficient instrument, reducing emissions where these reductions are least expensive (at least in theory, I'm not 100 % convinced this is entirely the case in reality) but it's likely to be somewhat close). It also generates income for the government, which it can use to finance climate mitigation programs and/or to compensate low-income households. Carbon pricing is also relatively easy to streamline across borders.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing should not be used as the only climate mitigation instrument, as it is unable to address some non-monetary issues such as a lack of information. It also does not address other issues relevant for sustainability, such as clean air (thinking about coal CCS) or minimization of high societal risks (related to the use of nuclear power). Furthermore, as long as there is not a broad societal agreement that strong emission reductions need to be made in the future and that this will translate to high CO2 emission costs, I'm not sure the most efficient and effective long-term investments will be made simply based on carbon pricing. That's why I would prefer a continuously increasing (minimum) CO2 tax or - if cap-and-trade is used - an increasing minimum price for CO2 certificates.
further_research: How well does carbon pricing work when CO2 prices are high over a prolonged time? How can it best be ensured that investors have certainty that in the long-term CO2 prices will be high and will be rising? (How can political and social acceptance be ensured?)
final_comments_cp_1: Well-done survey on an interesting topic. All the best for evaluating the survey results and for your research project in general.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: It is a fair instrument when based on the physical system. If worldwide used, it will lead to clear and precise impacts.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Firstly, it is not based on the physical system today, as it excludes several sectors, co-products and involves "magic numbers" that are supposed to be average values. Secondly,  if carbon taxes/etc. are defined in the EU, this will have a negative impact on global trading (e.g., the carbon border adjustment).
further_research: In my opinion, there is a gap between economy researchers and engineers. The first do not look over the physical meaning of carbon fluxes, whereas the second are not fully aware of the global impacts (in particular the associated/secondary impacts) of carbon pricing.
final_comments_cp_1: I think it is an interesting initiative. A suggestion would be to explore other subjects since people answering these surveys already tend to have a positive vision to climate change/sustainability/etc.

Research_interests_1: land use, agriculture, policy, climate, forestry, societal metabolism
comments_1: I'd suggest criteria organised as Feasibility (can it be done bio-physically), Viability (can it be done within the systems and processes defined by humans - e.g. economic or social) and Desirability (the questions of equity and fairness of burden sharing).  Its also worth being clear that in all cases there will be substantial ex ante uncertainty but that it not a reason to fail to act, rather there needs to be adaptive management - i.e. learning through doing.
comments_policy_rank_1: No policies that have any "negative" effects on powerful interests will be feasible without radical reform (the carbon lobbyists outnumbering delegates at COP26 for example).  The problem requires that voters and policy makers care more for 20 to 50 years time than now - and that is impossible with regressive populist politicians backed by unregulated right-wing media outlets

comments_background_1: I see there was no opportunity to comment on growth.  Just to be clear there are enough resources and wealth for us all globally to have an adequate and fulfilling existence with no more growth.  Growth of GDP has had zero benefit for working people in the developed world since late 1970's and globally the GPI has been flat for decades.  During this period we have seen the growth of the hyper-rich, levels of inequality not seen since the middle ages , the rise of kleptocracies and banking crime nearly destroying the world's economy.  Growth and the unregulated greed of the private sector is the cause of the problem not the solution.

criteria_5_SP: Sustainability - consider broad sustainability impacts and avoid tradeoffs
comments_1: Generally, instruments should not be rigidly predefined but should allow for adaptation and learning following initial deployment. Don't know if later questions will cover it, but process is extremely important, too.
comments_policy_rank_1: The answers depend greatly on the design of the instruments. For example, a flat carbon tax is regressive and hits low-income households and small business harder, but it could be designed to be very progressive.
comments_important_policies_1: A national framework is very important, but the real action should be driven through local / regional transformational sustainable development involving inclusive, diverse stakeholders in cooperative / collaborative processes.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: They can have a very direct and quick impact on emissions because they directly affect consumption whereas many other instruments are weaker, being more upstream and having longer latency. They also afford a high degree of control in that they can be quickly ramped up. Carbon tax has the advantage that revenue can be used to offset inequitable impacts on taxpayers, e.g. by reducing income tax for low earners - cap and trade is a market system and so compensating through taxes would be more complicated and less effective.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: They can be leaky, i.e. difficult to implement to ensure carbon emissions are fully captured (e.g. the difference between production and consumption-based accounting). They are at risk of political and corporate interference and capitalist exploitation that would severely affect their effectiveness, efficiency, and equity. Cap and Trade especially is a giveaway to the global financial industry that will use the commodification of carbon to perpetuate their power and the forces that are a major cause of the climate crisis in the first place. Cap and Trade also relies heavily on credits, including all kinds of dubious and unverifiable offset schemes.
further_research: #ИМЯ?
final_comments_cp_1: It took much longer than 10 minutes

Research_interests_1: energy policy, climate policy, renewable energy, policy instruments
comments_policy_rank_1: Feasibility is very context dependent. It is extremely difficult to translate from one country to another. My answer is based on "my" context.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Potential efficiency. Provides a good basic framework for change
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: To get acceptance you have to design them in ways that reduces efficiency. Does not work so well for driving technology change.
comments_cp_statements1_1: These questions depend very much on which time frame we are talking about. And just talking about carbon pricing as if it is a specific meaning is somewhat misleading. Most of the questions above depend on the specific design.
further_research: Issues around implementation.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Increase the cost of emissions that will transform the pricing structure of goods and services. Theoretically, it will steer R&D toward low-emission technologies, products, and services.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Implementation feasibility and adequate pricing structure.
further_research: How to actually implement carbon pricing at an appropriate price, and consumer reactions to the restructuring of prices for goods and services,

Research_interests_1: Support for climate mitigation policies, social aspects of energy sector decarbonisation, climate education
comments_1: Climate is a common good, so we need to regulate it on a global level, otherwise it would not be effective
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Affects carbon intensive consumption
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Difficult to implement in practice. It redistributes the wealth from rich to poor, the impact on emissions in not that clear
further_research: This tax often implies redistributive effects, a transfer of income from the rich to the poor. The transfer is either direct (in the Tax&Dividend formula) or through social transfers or allowances for lower-income earners. On the other hand, insufficient consideration of such effects means in turn social protests - the example of the yellow waistcoats in France. An interesting question is to what extent this affects the effectiveness of the carbon tax as a tool for reducing emissions.

comments_policy_rank_1: The equity answer is based on that, for example, tax revenue is not redesributed in order to compensate for poetntial regressive effects. Equity question was also hard to answer, because it will depends on which emissions source is priced, how that is used in various income groups etc
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Simple principle, strong signal (given that price is high enough) to abate emissions. Also affect the price of the product that generate emissions in its production. Getting price right (by pricing externalities), including on the consumer level, is critical for reducing emissions to (close to) net zero
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Can be regressive, but the regressive nature can be dealt with redistribution. However, redistribution schemes may be hard to set up so that everyone is satisfied. The whole scheme, i.e. price and redribution, may be hard communicate to voters etc.
further_research: Prices, information vs regulation on CH4 and N2O emissions in the  agricultural sector
final_comments_cp_1: interesting. Looking forward to see the results of the research.

Research_interests_1: climate change, macroeconomy, inequality, energy, public finance
comments_1: We need comprehensive evaluation with different criteria. in order to analyse synergies, trade-offs, best routes for compromises : effectiveness, equity, efficiency. Political factors are important to analyse, but should not overweight other more "objectives" evaluation. As there is much uncertainty and debotes on evaluation, the sensitivity of the evaluation to competing assumptions about the functionning of the economy and social preferences must be included in the evalautions. This would improve the use of evaluations in public debates.
comments_policy_rank_1: What matter is the policy package as there is always a combination of instruments. Unfortunatly most of the evaluations compare individual instruments. For instance, generalised direct regulations would have a high welfare cost because of informational asymetries. But target regulations or targeted subsidies is part of the solution and can reduce the social costs if associated with higher carbon prices.
comments_important_policies_1: Direct regulation and subsidies should be targeted and associated with carbon prices and accompanying measures to vulnerable industries and households. The mix of instruments should also change overtime (more subsidies first, but then increased carbon prices, etc.). Information is crucial to give concrete goals to actors about the time of transformation the society seeks to reach (and for political support : to understand and accept policy instruments)
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon prices provide a signal to all actors and informational costs. Public revenues are available for mitigating social and economic short-term impacts of higher energy prices. It makes costs visible to all (contrary to other policies that create costs, but less visible : subsidies, standards, etc.)
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: A carbon price should be accompanied with compensating measures towards the most vulnerables (sectors, households). Many political failures do to insufficient consensus about how to conciliate higher energy prices, with other objectives : equity, competitiveness, macroeconomic performance, information, etc. A carbon tax cannot be implemented alone, it should be associated with other complementary policies
comments_2nd_order_1: A large part, but maybe less recently (do to political difficulties)
further_research: Evaluation of carbon prices not alone, but within different policy packages. Comprehensive analysis of carbon prices with respect to multiple economic and social objectives. Decompartimentalise environmental economics and general economics (public finance, finance, macroeconomics, poverty and inequalities). Analysis of arguments and beliefs about carbon prices and other alternative options. Analysis of uncertainty and sensitivity of carbon price evaluations to different positive and normative assumptions (second best analysis).
final_comments_cp_1: Interesting, although focus groups may be more informative. Many questions and answers would need explanations and discussions. I wonder if you will be able to really explain the results. Please inform me.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Transparency and ease of application — market solves the problem
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Small geographical coverage
further_research: The influence between carbon pricing and inequality; how carbon pricing can work if the goal is zero emissions? (should the price be infinite?)

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Equal opportunity for implementation. Tangible method of evaluation through finances to determine feasibility. A mechanism for funding of projects that would not have been feasible.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Country specific economic situations and progress not taken into account
further_research: Taking into account the impact on different countries, ie developed or developing

comments_1: All of the criteria are actually crucial, but I tried to prioritize them.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Simple, effective and efficient. It provides an incentive to businesses and consumers to find the best way for themselves to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions. This probably results in better solutions than if it were left to the state to design all the policies.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Equity is the main problem. The heaviest burdens might fall on the weakest shoulders, unless compensating measures are introduced. And those are unlikely to be simple or efficient.
further_research: One gap (at least in my knowledge) is to what extent the steward is rewarded, e.g. agricultural practices that increase carbon storage in the soil. Another is the impact on income distribution.

Research_interests_1: energy policy, adaptation, energy transition, sustainable mobility, nature based solutions
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Efficiency / least cost in theory. Cap and trade also gives certainty on environmental outcome. Could generate revenue in short term (then in theory the revenue generation potential would decrease, with a reduction in the carbon-generating activity/adoption of cleaner processes)
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: political acceptability, carbon leakage, potentially regressive impacts. Carbon tax does not provide certainty about environmental outcome.
further_research: Potentially regressive impact. Link between environmental performance and (in)elasticity of demand/supply

Research_interests_1: Climate change mitigation policy, carbon sequestration, biochar
criteria_5_SP: Systems-oriented, i.e. not causing emissions in other sectors.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Taxing the 'common bad' gives a direct price signal. CO2-emissions are distributed according to wealth, albeit not linearly. Gives tax revenues for investments in green technology and infrastructure.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Can be unjust (but can also be compensated for by other policies). Gives tax revenues (which is frowned upon in some places).
further_research: Pricing of carbon sinks is severely under-researched. Policies to mitigate unjust transition. Regional development (and/or transition) linked to carbon pricing.

Research_interests_1: agriculture, ghg mitigation, climate impacts, bioenergy
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Increased efficiency, providing incentives to reduce GHG emissions specifically (rather than change practices without a direct focus on change in GHG) and to reduce them in a cost-effective manner. GHG emissions reductions should be coming from the lowest-cost sources under a well-designed carbon pricing policy, with flexibility for sources to choose the most cost-effective ways to achieve those reductions.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Requires careful carbon accounting and monitoring to ensure estimated reductions in emissions are accurate. To the extent there are negative health, environmental, or other impacts associated with activities emitting GHG, allowing those sources to trade carbon permits with others (under cap and trade) leaves negative impacts on the local area higher than under direct regulatory or other approaches with less flexibility.
further_research: Many of the key issues relate to assessment of potential damages (e.g., social cost of carbon) to inform value of carbon tax or number of permits (under cap and trade) to be issued, how to address discounting over time, dynamics, effects of banking and borrowing, detailed carbon accounting.

Research_interests_1: climate policy, climate law and economics
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Money talks: carbon pricing provides a monetary incentive to reduce carbon (or: greenhouse gas) emissions.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The cap under cap-and-trade can be set too high due to information asymmetry or lobbying, while the tax level under a carbon tax can be set too low for achieving a pre-defined emissions reduction target.
comments_cp_statements1_1: Cap-and-trade and carbon taxes perform quite differently in terms of effectiveness and low-carbon innovation (as well as feasibility). In that sense, the questions on "carbon pricing" are too general.
further_research: It is still not clear whether carbon floor prices improve or deteriorate the efficiency of carbon markets. And we would need to know to what extent industry lobbies have been able to influence the design (and, thus, the efficiency) of the different carbon markets across the world.
final_comments_cp_1: A (in my view necessary) differentiation between cap-and-trade and carbon taxation was missing, but for the rest: really interesting survey! Looking forward to reading the results.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon tax captures the cost of externalities in the product or goods or services
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: If same carbon price is not adopted worldwide, it will only shift the emissions to countries with lower or no carbon tax.
further_research: People should be made aware that carbon pricing is the cost they pay for their GHG emitting activities. We must pay the price of our contribution in global warming.

Research_interests_1: Industrial, agricultural, forestry, planning, energy, waste
comments_1: The key issue here is verifying emission reductions. The economic factors are all relative in terms of carbon economics the indigenous peoples safeguard the most wealth.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: In economic theory this should drive emission reduction. However, will probably be offset with inflation and markets getting used to higher prices.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Prices are too low and being manipulated by Fossil fuel interests primarily to avoid the tax through selling carbon credits to others  (From carbon storage processes) that they should bear the cost for. The voluntary nature of the schemes makes it impossible to achieve the necessary scale. The farmers need intensive practices to maintain economic viability, so we must adjust the relative price of food so that sustainable farming practices can be adopted - this would require an economic value assessment/ reduction of other human activities (e.g. construction)
comments_cp_statements1_1: Carbon pricing has to be set across the whole range of human activities otherwise it becomes a political football for those with the strongest voices.
comments_2nd_order_1: Effective carbon pricing policy that would work at scale needs to supported by a massive contingency transition plan/operation to deal with the impacts on sector activities/employment etc
further_research: Its largely voluntary - needs to be mandatory. Contingency transition planning impact on for example farmers, Oil and gas workers. Need to define what exactly net zero is in terms of land use carbon intensity reduction and sequestration. Both, from all activities should result in reversing global warming. Carbon pricing should increase if activity leads to an increase in carbon intensity and a decrease in sequestration. Monitoring (e.g. satellite, drones) will be key research areas for development with key sensor and location technologies. Peat-land restoration will be a key issue in turning land that has become a carbon emitter into a carbon store.
comments_background_1: We can only solve this problem at the required scale if we all work together. Unfortunately this may take too long as we have been deceived/obstructed by governments and fossil fuel interests over the last 30 years.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Efficiency - in theory at least. Acceptability - especially amongst polluters

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing attaches an economic value to an activity that generates carbon and hence makes use of market forces to regulate emissions at a lower level of required oversight compared to carbon tax or cap-and-trade
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The very act of finding the "right" price to every unit of carbon generated is the biggest challenge to start with. Furthermore, it may not be the case that the "right" price is a constant value but rather it may be dependent on quantity of emissions for a firm.
further_research: Empirical studies of firms' behaviors to varying levels of carbon pricing.
