Research_interests_1: emission markets, carbon dioxide removal, energy policy
comments_1: Efficient policy also serves equity.
comments_policy_rank_1: The equity of taxes and cap and trades depends on what you  do with the revenues. This question doe not allow a nuanced response, which is very important in this case.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Low cost, flexibility, international linkability. A price mechanism can induce a much more efficient inter-temporal pattern of decarbonization.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Selecting an appropriate tax rate is difficult. A high enough rate is not politically feasible. Updates in response to new information is very hard. Some of the revenue should be used for distributional equity.
further_research: Updating the tax or the cap in response to new information is the key challenge for price mechanisms in addressing carbon emissions. Economists (and policy makers) do not know ex ante the "correct" price. The price mechanism must adjust to new information and preferably should do so according to a pre-announced and predictable rule.
comments_background_1: The economic growth questions are a bit loaded. Growth in knowledge is essential for progress. Growth in material throughput can be much slower (even negative for many resources). Population growth can slow without harming future per capita consumption. So one must be careful in interpreting statements about the necessity of "growth".
final_comments_cp_1: See comment on previous question.

Research_interests_1: energy policy, climate change mitigation, geoengineering
comments_1: This is not a good survey.  These questions are far to vague and do not identify specifiic mitigation policies.
comments_policy_rank_1: Again, you should disaggregate issues for the different main sectors of the economy.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: None.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: If the tax is low as discussed in the literature, such as $200 per ton or less, it will have little impact, but varied according to the sector.  If much higher it will probably crash the economy if implemented as quickly as needed.  Regulation would be much more effective than carbon taxes, since a modest tax will take far too long to have much effect, and will not affect rich and upper middle class people much.
further_research: We know almost nothing about what effect that carbon pricing would have on each sector of the economy at a price level high enough to change behavior.
final_comments_cp_1: Surveys like this are not important or interesting.  They do not help generate new good ideas for mitigating climate change.  We need much more detailed discussions for each major energy end-use and land use.  I really don't care what other so-called "experts" think, especially economists who are usually misguided!  Engineers are often more helpful when thinking about how to mitigate climate change.

Primary_research_field_14_SP: Energy and climate policy modelling and analysis
comments_policy_rank_1: The equity impact of carbon taxes and cap and trade are highly dependent on how revenues are returned.  They can be very equitable if designed correctly
comments_important_policies_1: I increasingly think we need policy mixes that combine a variety of broad market based policies, to set the overall market context, with sector/technology specific incentives, R&D supports and regulations to create specific signals for transformative change and innovation to support the provision of emerging technologies/ fuels
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: The policy has a broad impact across the economy and can incentivize the lowest cost abatement actions.  It sets the overall market context by defining the cost of GHG emissions
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: This policy, when strong enough to have an impact, is generally not politically acceptable. It does not provide a specific signal to industry to supply a given fuel or technology.
further_research: not right now

comments_policy_rank_1: Equity depends more on details of the policies (recycling schemes for tax revenues, which regulations in which sectors, adoption subsidies for which products) so is impossible to answer in general.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: With cap and trade, there is a guaranteed outcome for emissions. The most efficient measures are taken. The policy is simple.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Equity impacts depend on additional policies (recycling). Danger of leakage without CBAM. Generally audience does not like additional taxes or price increases.
further_research: Public attitudes towards carbon pricing several years after introducing the pricing mechanism.

Research_interests_1: climate economics, energy economics, renewable resources
comments_policy_rank_1: When it comes to carbon tax or cap-and-trade,  the equity question depends crucially on how revenues generated by the system are used.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: As a practical policy option, I would say that the the attractiveness of carbon pricing depends a lot on how the system is implemented. For instance, the income profile of the incidence of a carbon tax depends crucially on how the revenues are spend. Regardless I think that any climate policy mix must contain a significant portion of to come close to optimal policy.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Seems to be difficult to get public support for carbon pricing policies.
comments_cp_statements1_1: Some of the answers depend on the realized price. A high price is required to induce significant change (e.g. point d) but I think the price could be made large enough to lead to zero emissions. Whether such a high price is politically feasible is another issue.
further_research: Distributional consequences of carbon pricing schemes. Quantification of effects of carbon pricing with boundedly rational agents.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: If done right and priced expensive enough, it can give economic incentives for carbon emission reduction.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Market mechanics are unreliable and the goal of carbon emission reduction is not enforced directly. Mostly political pressure will prevent reasonable high prices and taxes. Some firms might be able to afford high amounts of carbon emission. The effect is also highly dependent on national and regional political, cultural and social contexts.
further_research: Contextual effects on the efficiency of carbon pricing. control and measuremnt of carbon emission by firms.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Very appealing from an economic efficiency perspective
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Highly complex and politically infeasible (or nearly so) globally across countries
comments_cp_statements1_1: c) I dislike this question as it seems to imply that energy rebound is a bad thing.  Energy rebound creates economic welfare.  This creates a tradeoff especially for poorer countries and between UN Strategic Development goals.  (See IPCC SR1.5 for a discussion of this)
further_research: Much more research needed on the feasibility of carbon pricing across disparate countries (e.g., not within the EU)
final_comments_cp_1: Feels slightly tilted toward climate policy in industrialized countries and away from the needs of those in energy poverty, where policy prescriptions can be much different.  And seems to lean toward a degrowth perpective.  Interesting survey, though.  I'll be interested to see the results!

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: disincentivizes fossil-fuel intensive practices. Places responsibility for emissions reductions/ cost of emissions reductions on major emitting states and corporations
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Offsets burden for mitigation to developing nations. encourages business as usual without making necessary changes for on-shore mitigation. Disproportionally places burden of carbon tax on low-income households, especially in relation to petrol pricing.
further_research: social factors which drive support for carbon pricing. how to avoid the burden falling upon low-income households - optimal balance between price of goods and emissions benefits.

Research_interests_1: Coastal Engineering, Energy, energy modelling, natural hazards, mitigation, adaptation
comments_1: This appears to be a biased and incorrectly formulated question. Essentially, you present what appears to look like a 5 point Likert scale, yet the value in the middle is not neutral, but "important". Hence, the conclusions of your questionnaire could be invalid due to the bias in your question.
comments_important_policies_1: Again, another biased question. The results of such a question are unclear... hence I am not answering.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Makes coal obviously more expensive. Easy to tax, and clearly leads to the decommissioning of coal power... and often the building of gas plants, but also renewables.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Makes coal more expensive... which is something rich countries can afford, but not poor countries. Hence the results of the present rounds of negotiations (COP26)
further_research: Not one of my areas of study.
comments_background_1: I am definitively a leftie on most points, though I do not fully agree with a "communist" society. Please come to Japan to see what a capitalist model that generally cares about society looks like (though it is also not perfect...)
final_comments_cp_1: I made some comments before. Two of your questions are biased, and probably invalid.

weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Systems based on carbon taxes or cap-and-trade are different. Cap-and-trade systems are less exhaustive, and are not able to ensure an appropriate carbon price

weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: It influences Competitiveness

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: It can be market efficient. The ones that emit carbon have to pay for it. It's relatively easily implemented. Is relatively well-suited as a global/regional policy.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: It can lead to inequality as only those that can afford the price are able to emit. So companies who earned a lot with polluting can continue to do so. It does not account for historic emissions. A higher price does not guarantee the reduction that is needed to prevent catastrophic climate change. There is substantial lobby power to lower the price of carbon and thereby make it less effective.
further_research: Better understanding if carbon pricing can really help reduce carbon emissions as needed. Impacts on inequality. Best mixture of carbon pricing with other climate policies.

Research_interests_1: resource economics, resource markets, numerical modeling
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing is the first-best policy because it identifies the cheapest mitigation costs.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: For a carbon cap-and-trade system, cap setting is challenging but crucial for an effective instrument. Similarly, carbon taxes are arbitrarily set by political decision makers. Both policies might have regressive distributional effects which need to be properly identified, addressed and communicated to ensure political feasibility of the instrument - all very challenging tasks.
further_research: effect of regional carbon prices on global mitigation and global resource use; feasibility of linking regional systems (how to achieve, how to ensure stability)

Research_interests_1: environmental modelling, land-use change, energy transitions
comments_1: Hard to choose, but given the very serious crisis situation and the very slow response currently, effectiveness, followed by feasibility and equity should take priority
comments_policy_rank_1: it's basically about making very rapid adjustments to a low carbon economy. I don't think that can be done on a reasonable timescale without a carbon tax combined with very well structured and carefully considered direct regulation. Cap and trade is a poor, though not useless, alternative. Any top-down policy risks exacerbating existing social divisions and powerful actors will fight to ensure that carbon taxes or restrictions will disproportionately affect the less well off...
comments_important_policies_1: I think the importance of R&D is overstated. We have the tools already, but lack the political will to use them. By supporting education, the political system might one day be forced to change direction. That day will unfortunately be later than we might like, but will eventually arrive I think.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing works in favor of the existing economic status quo, which uses markets to obtain or diffuse innovations for the lowest possible cost. The reason it is likely to be very effective is because our economies already have the means to incorporate the adjustment relatively easily.  A high carbon price, obligation to multinationals to pay it, fair and appropriate carbon border adjustments, exemptions for small businesses and individuals, and a complete elimination of subsidies for fossil fuels can have a very powerful effect - if these measures are taken firmly & together.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Markets can only work if they are not distorted by subsidies. Obviously, as long as governments are willing to subsidize fossil fuel companies - i.e with free permits to pollute - making carbon expensive could actually be harmful - i.e by diverting public funds towards compensating polluters.
comments_cp_statements1_1: respect to d) and i). Its not about rationality - very expensive coal oil and gas will dissuade large emitters of carbon, I think that's very evident. The risks are that governments, e.g. China will simply subsidize their way out of the problem until they've used up all their coal - personally I don't think that's very likely - or that governments all over the world will try to pass the cost of carbon onto the consumer by allowing affected multinationals to charge excessive prices for basic commodities like energy. I think that is an almost inevitable short-to-mid term consequence, likely to lead to social and political unrest.
comments_2nd_order_1: Hard to say except that I am concerned by the focus of many researchers in my field on what I consider to be micro issues like trying to change individual behaviour. It's important in the long-term, but it's a question of scale and urgency. I've been involved in projects that talk breathlessly about social inflexion points leading to a cascading societal transition for over 5 years and I do not see strong evidence that this is really happening. But I do think that a combination of strong pressure from citizens and a high price on carbon could get us where we need to be (eventually).
further_research: Yes. Societal responses and perceptions of fairness and unfairness. Deep study of how to price carbon without hitting low income families and rural areas. Polluter pays not Citizen pays, that's something we seem to have forgotten. We need to leave the so-called "consumer" our of the debate in my opinion (the idea of "consumer power" is neoliberal brainwashing from the 1980s - are consumers who hate Amazon going to stop it? - of course not - ditto with Big Energy) and look to businesses and governments for cross-scale cross border solutions. And please shut up about Electric Cars. It's not a magic solution, though of course big business loves it, why wouldn't they?
comments_background_1: I'm certainly a fair way over to the left, but probably don't identify with all conventional "left" ideas - I'm more interested in functioning states that big states (communist dictatorships and fascist dictatorships are nearly identical IMO), and I fully support small businesses. But I loathe the idea that markets solve everything, they are not "free" and never have been. But as you see from my answers, if markets do solve one thing, they probably can address carbon emissions. At the same time, citizens must be empowered and must hold corrupt elites to account. Old fashioned ideas like "growth" need to be substituted for economic models that operate within planetary boundaries.
final_comments_cp_1: Interesting survey, would like to see the results,

comments_policy_rank_1: It is difficult to know whether this task is meaningful, because the design of the instrument is as important--or more important--for all these dimensions as the choice of instrument. For some (like information), I guess it's relatively uncontroversial, but for the others it depends a) how the instrument is designed, and b) how each of your criteria are interpreted (and, crucially, over what timescale)
comments_important_policies_1: I find this difficult to answer. They are all very or extremely important attributes of an effective policy mix.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Sends consistent signals across the portion of the economy to which it is applied; generates lower cost emissions reductions; provides an ongoing signal for consumer choice and innovation
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: It has proved politically very difficult to implement carbon prices at a rate high enough to generate transformative change, until other policies have created the right conditions in a sector (i.e. bringing forward new technologies). Some types of decision (e.g. home retrofit) are less influenced by relatively small differences in cost of energy and carbon prices would have to be extremely high to make change happen.
comments_cp_statements1_1: I think a dynamic perspective is important: the political feasibility of carbon pricing at high rates can change over time, influenced by the state of technology in a sector.
comments_2nd_order_1: Hard to say: there's a lot of wiggle room between "important", "very important" and "extremely important" - I'm not sure the distinctions between 'important' and 'very/extremely' tell you very much
further_research: There has been surprising little strong empirical research on how carbon pricing affects innovation. More research on the political economy of carbon pricing would be valuable: how instrument/policy mix choice can be made more robust to the existence of political coalitions, the state of mitigation technology options, etc.

Research_interests_1: energy policy, energy economics, climate policy
comments_policy_rank_1: A cap-and-trade system would have a high effectiveness (certainty of realization of the emissions-reduction target). However, as in the EU ETS, granting green investments in third-party countries as well as having additional climate policies in place (--> waterbed effect) decreases its effectiveness. I thus assume that you mean a "pure" cap-and-trade program.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: *) Leads to an efficient outcome if price is set right (i.e. according to the social costs of carbon), according to economic theory. *) Generates a double dividend, that can be used to bring about social equity and/or for other policy measures. *) May work much faster than many other climate policies. *) Technological neutrality --> no "winner picking" of technologies by imperfectly informed policy makers. *)
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: *) In many cases: public mistrust. *) As opposed to many other policies, the costs (= carbon price) are not concealed/implicit, so that tax payers become "alarmed". *) Other additional policies have zero abatement effect under an emissions cap (= waterbed effect), but politicians still may want to apply additional climate policies (probably out of ignorance). *) If the level of the carbon price is expected to be low in the future and or subject to great uncertainty, it may send low investment incentives into green assets.
further_research: *) Empirical studies on the short- and long-term emissions abatement effects of carbon pricing are scarce (probably due to the fact that most countries did not have "meaningful" carbon prices). Only since 2018, we have been experiencing rising carbon prices in the EU ETS, which may be exploited in current empirical research. *) It would be very interesting to assess if carbon pricing can incentivize investments in green assets and green infrastructure (e.g. in expectation of relatively high carbon prices in the future).

comments_1: The criteria listed above ar of course extremely important. What I find challenging in my own field, trying to understand how to shift towards environmentally sustainable consumption patterns, is quantification. It is understandable, that policies with quantifiable criteria are easier to discuss. However, the interconnected nature of household consumption and daily activities make it challenging to quantify implications of policies.
effectiveness_7_SP: Changing infrastructure i.e., urban planning, transport systems etc.
comments_policy_rank_1: If I think about household consumption (food, housing, transport, consumption of other goods and services), an important policy measure was not explicitly listed in the policy measures: Infrastructure. I think the allocation of space for different transport modes and urban planning has a huge impact to set the opportunity space in which citizens operate. There is great potential but at the same time, we have to deal with the infrastructure we have, which makes infrastructure related policies slow to take effect.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon tax, if applied globally, would have the potential to avoid carbon leakage and address embedded emissions in all products and services
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon tax can have considerable impacts on people and populations already struggling to make basic needs met. The welfare distributional effects need to be considered carefully.
further_research: How to ensure that carbon pricing will support societies to shift towards more equal access to basic necessities. In other words, those consuming the most should cut down their consumption and emissions  a lot while people who struggle to meet basic needs should have improved access to meet their needs.
comments_background_1: What comes to the role of economic growth in society, this is not my own field of research. However, I have become to doubt if economic growth can be sustained if we want to restore nature and decrease GHG emissions. Economic growth has brought better livelihoods for many, but according to my understanding, this has happened at the cost of nature. I think we need a debate if it is honest to expect that we can combine economic growth with the improved condition of the environment and more fair distribution of welfare among people.

Research_interests_1: climate change policy, long-term policymaking, climate change politics
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Evidence that carbon pricing reduces emissions; depending on their design, carbon pricing can be quite economically efficient; carbon taxes in particular are relatively easy to implement since they can be layered on top of governments existing tax collection structures
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: They impose highly visible costs on voters and business, which can be made salient by climate policy opponents; once implemented they are politically difficult to increase for the reason mentioned above; they have dominated the climate policy discussion since the 1970s even though efforts to adopt them have repeatedly failed in many countries, particularly the US; they can be regressive, which further reduces their political feasibility, especially in countries with high levels of inequality
further_research: Carbon pricing has received enough attention by researchers, especially economists. I would encourage social scientists to think about the design of other policies that can drive emissions reductions and that are politically feasible.

comments_1: Efficiency: The cost of policy instruments must be evaluated in light of the cost of unabated climate change. Equity: Equity issues must be resolved once the ideal policy instrument has been identified. Social and economic issues can be adjusted - natural laws such as ecosystem boundaries cannot! Feasibility: Implementation of an instrument is a sociopolitical decision. Science should explore the best option based on ecological necessities without consideration of "political" feasibility.
comments_policy_rank_1: Effectiveness, efficiency, equity and feasibility of all instrument that imply taxes or levies depend on the use of the revenues (e.g. redistribution to population, investment in clean-tech-projects...)
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Economically efficient. Carbon tax would be very efficient if raised at the source and reflected in product prices --> true cost accounting is the most effective and efficient policy instrument. It has to be installed globally.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon Trading (as currently proposed within the EU): Not effective if cap is not lowered and emission permits are issued for free. Obsolete technologies are maintained because they allow the issuance of carbon credits. Many opportunities for fraud. Problems with additionality. A problem that evolved from a corrupt system cannot be resolved within the same system. Equity problems if unequal wealth distribution is not addressed at the same time. Cap-and-trade is impossible in a net-zero-GHG-emission world (unless there are significant carbon sinks).
further_research: How to reach global consensus for the implementation of a carbon tax (sociopsychological studies needed). How to address negative side effects, e.g. that poor people are more affected than richer people. (Global) Introduction of a carbon tax needs to lead to a more equitable distribution of (material) wealth. The capitalist economic system nurtures fraud, free riders etc. . Carbon pricing can only be implemented within a new economic framework that does also address issues as uneven distribution of income and wealth. How such a transition can be achieved smoothly on a global level should be investigated.

further_research: The impact of uniform taxes compared to energy carrier specific taxes perhaps?

Research_interests_1: social outcomes of climate policies, greenhouse gas emissions, mitigation pathways
comments_policy_rank_1: For all dimensions, design considerations are important: e.g. means testing adoption subsidies can alleviate negative distributional outcomes; as can revenue recycling from direct regulation or taxes. There is also probably a negative correlation between effectiveness (e.g. strength of a carbon price) and feasibility. Lastly, some policies may be less effective in the short term (and hence more feasible), compared to the longer term as they shift underlying societal conditions around technology availability, prices and desirability (R&D subsidies, information provision).
comments_important_policies_1: I think a policy mix is needed, taking into account the differing political and economic dimensions of each sector. Cap and trade may have a role due to path dependencies, e.g. as an existing power sector policy in Europe that could be strengthened. But in other contexts without these dependencies I do not consider it a useful approach due to its limited ex-post effectiveness.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Speaking just to carbon taxes, its main strengths are the cross-sectoral nature, transparency, clear incentive, generation of revenue, and flexibility (e.g. price can be increased over time, or when there is high political capital)
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Again, just on carbon taxes: perceived (e.g. in the transport sector) or real (e.g. in heating) negative distributional effects. It's flexibility is also a weakness. For example, governments may choose not to increase the price, or actively stabilise it to gain political capital (see the annual cancellation of fuel duty "increases" in the UK). Interest groups may bet that they can influence future prices and may continue locking in carbon-intensive capital stocks. Direct regulation (e.g. moratoria on new coal plants, ICE engines) may send a clearer signal without such loopholes. Direct regulation can be more transparent (a ban is simple to communicate) and can be politically supported by growing anti-fossil norms. Finally, if carbon tax revenues are recycled as lump sum transfers, overall effectiveness may be reduced. It is all about design...
further_research: Learning on ex-post policy effectiveness, continuously updated as new policies and projects are initiated. Understanding of broader social outcomes, beyond distributional effects.

comments_policy_rank_1: Comment re the efficiency rating: I answer assuming the measure does achieve the objective, however my 'gut-feeling' is that thus far (and that might be due to the low price on carbon/relatively low carbon tax), fiscal instruments like carbon tax and cap-and-trade might have slowed emissions compared to a counter-factual where the tax/market had not been in place, but I would not go so far as to say that these measures have worked in terms of reaching our mitigation objectives - which we time and time again fail to do.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: The theoretical strength (if it works as intended, that is), is that it uses market mechanisms to phase out the 'bads' while promoting the 'goods', making environmentally friendly options the 'rational' choice, and also in theory, enabling us finding the best options at the lowest (public) cost.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Think it's safe to say that the low price on carbon to date, and the reliance on these market-mechanisms, has delayed the mitigation action that we need, making it altogether more expensive to reach the climate objectives today, than had the work started more seriously. Due to industry and business lobbying, and due to all the exemptions (and unfortunate fossil fuel subsidies still in place), the mechanisms haven't worked as well in practice, as promised in theory.
comments_cp_statements1_1: The willingness to pay in order to pollute seems to be high, and if the alternative choices are lacking, then it becomes a very inequitable picture of the well-resourced continuing more or less business as usual, just at a higher cost, while the less-resourced are those most affected by the carbon pricing measure. This is hardly effective since we know there is a close link between level of income and carbon-intensity of footprints.
further_research: Perhaps more focus on the formal and informal processes of influence on deciding the price/trading system, in comparison with other measures such as direct regulation, subsidies, R&D, etc.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: I cannot think how we can mitigate climate change without price-incentives. Strength of the approaches are that carbon prices may create an incentive to cooperate (as discussed by behavioral economists recently)
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: i do not know if it is sufficiently clear how the price-elasticities are  (i.e., would carbon prices deter the richest 1, 5, or 10% of the society)
further_research: how do consumers react to carbon prices, there is actually not much known about that...

weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: (i) The total amount of carbon emission allowances need to be closely surveyed and updated to avoid that carbon price becomes irrelevant (as during the economic crisis). (ii) You can emit if you can pay for it. This is a bad message in general.

Research_interests_1: climate policy, CO2 pricing, decarbonization scenarios
comments_policy_rank_1: It often depends on the design of the policy Instrument - therefore answering the above questions this way is quite difficult. An ETS should deliver on a set target if the cap is met, however, if the System is opened up in a way it may happen that the cap is not met (as an example for the effectiveness) - applies to all policies mentioned above.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Putting a Price to Carbon should indicate to the consumer which consum decision is better for the climate. It should also make it profitable for firms to invest into low-carbon Technologies. Low-cost Options should be realized first compared to more costly Options so that total costs should be as low as possible.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: There are many reasons why a Carbon Price itself does not work to realize the necessary measures. We have high risk Investments into new Technologies that Need R&D funding, we have Investment barriers where the sufficient amount of Money needed for the initial Investment is simply not available to make a more climate friendly decision (even though it may be more financially attractive over the lifetime of the Technology), we have high requirements for Returns on Investments in industry, which despite of Carbon Prices cannot be met, we have Investment dilemmas where the owner of a house does not live in the house and hence does not Profit from the Investment into insulation or a new renewable heating System. And there are necessary Investments into large Infrastructure Systems that can also not be addressed via Carbon Prices. To address those barriers other Instruments are needed
comments_cp_statements1_1: again, answering the questions depends often on the design of the Instruments in question and also on the sectors where emissions reductions are needed
further_research: The design of the Carbon pricing system in the context of an existing policy mix deserves severe Attention and Research as the policy mix can widely vary (over time, sectors, countries, ...). Need for stabilization mechanisms (e.g. deletion of allowances due to other policies, ...)

comments_1: feasibility should include legality and administrative capacity to implement the policy
comments_policy_rank_1: my view is that there is no insturment type that is per nature more effective, efficient, equitable or feasible. It all depends on the instrument's design and the context of its implementation. Research needs to focus on that.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: the price signal they produce, if high enough, can influence industries' behavior and investors' behavior. If the industries can upgrade, this may push them to upgrade. If not, it may push them out or oblige them to invest in offsets.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: we never get a high-enough price, mechanism is complex and requires extremely high administrative and institutional capacity to govern effectively. Carbon tax is somewhat easier but it adds to the tax burden, revenue use is a major issue for most governments. Regressive impacts on vulnerable groups and industries are hard to mitigate
comments_2nd_order_1: policy mix is key in my view. Then trade-offs and potential cross-effects of policy instruments is a concern that does not get enough attention. At the same time, expecting the whole transition to be driven exclusively by carbon pricing is problematic because the institutional basis for such a mechanism to work is absent or partial in many countries in the world. China is a good example of that. Studies carefully attributing the  past and observed effects (not the projected effects) of different carbon pricing mechanisms, as opposed to other policies and/or other factors such as economic slowdown or de-industrialization / economic restructuring and delocalization are needed on emissions reduction.  Furthermore, the "polluter pays" principle embodied in carbon pricing mechanisms find their limits when the polluter is everybody, and especially individuals who are locked-in carbon-dependent infrastructures, ways of life, geographies and employments. Positive, appealing transition pathways need to be drawn for them before they're punished for not supporting it.
further_research: interaction with other measures based on real data instead of projections. Impact of carbon pricing on institutional investors in different markets. impact of carbon pricing on consumer prices based on real data to see how much is absorbed by the producers and how much is passed on to consumers.
comments_background_1: economic growth is a meaningless indicator to me. It all depends on what grows. climate policy should not about growth or de-growth but about selecting what should grow and what not according to sustainability criteria.

Research_interests_1: Energy policy, renewable energy integration, electrification
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: There are strong theoretical evidence that carbon pricing is an efficient policy instrument to control emission levels. Also, real life (local, sectorial) examples of this working are not difficult to find.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Unless the carbon price is global (geographically and covering all economic sectors) there are substantial difficulties, especially the risk of carbon leakage, which in it self typically leads to exemptions in locations with a carbon price to sectors exposed to competition. Also, the fact that a carbon price without any form of correction would hit necessary consumption equally hard as excessive consumption which in turn can exacerbate poverty for lower income segments of the world. Therefore there are typically significant equity issues with this instrument.
further_research: I would say it is probably the most well studied policy mechanism there is, therefore it is difficult to point at anything specific that is not covered by research yet. Still, even though there are examples of work touching on this, it would be good to focus on measures to reduce carbon leakage like import taxes with a carbon component between zones of different carbon price levels.

comments_policy_rank_1: It is not possible to answer these questions without knowing the details of the policy design, and how instruments are combined with other measures in a policy mix. Also the answers will vary across countries - what is feasable at one place may not work well another place.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: It is effective and efficient if the price is high enough. Spurring incremental behavioral change.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: It can not be the only measure, it needs to be combined with others in a policy mix. It can turn people away from climate policy at all. It can be unfair. further_research: The role of carbon pricing in policy mixes. Changes in the role of carbon pricing over time. The role of carbon prizes in the Global South.
final_comments_cp_1: Many of the questions do not have any answer that is true in general, you should have allowed this as an answer-alternative. You should have asked about geographical differences and opened up for policy mix situations.

final_comments_cp_1: I would conclude that carbon pricing is an important/interesting tool, but should not be the only one at all. What kind of growth are we talking about? Some sectors have to grow to face climate change, others have to degrow. The composition matters more than a generic "economic growth".

criteria_5_SP: Transformativeness, i.e. taking into account the need to promote radically alternative futures whilst accepting the need to do away with system inertia. In other words, incremental reform  may not always be most appropriate
comments_1: Another important criterion is cumulativeness, i.e. taking into account the need to lock in positive outcomes and ratcheting up level of ambition and delivery
equity_7_SP: new forms of representation to more actively include those most vulnerable to loss
feasible_7_SP: increased representation and transparency about decision-making
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Combining a long-term and short-term price signal. putting a value on carbon. Level playing field (depending on design implementation) is in theory positive.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Grandfathering and exemptions are a huge problem, decreasing legitimacy and effectiveness. Focus on production emissions and lack of border adjustments are problematic. Fluctuations of carbon price (notably due to speculation and gaming) are a problem.
comments_cp_statements1_1: Questions like j) entirely depend on discretionary implementation choices. The yellow vests movement has inter alia shown that carbon pricing (petrol tax) can be perceived as entirely unfair if no transparency on the use of public revenues accrued.
comments_2nd_order_1: the privileged framing in sustainability transitions studies is that isolated instruments are not effective. The important way to look at policy intervention is through the notion of policy mix, i.e. the combination of instruments, their layering, their temporal articulation (to address chicken-and-egg problems)
further_research: 'carbon pricing' needs to be unpacked as otherwise it is too abstract, primarily evaluated through economic models (rational choice), and entirely oblivious to design and implementation issues. Live experiments so far (e.g. EU ETS) show that there as almost as many loopholes as positive outcomes. What is at stake is the legitimacy of governing GHG mitigation
comments_background_1: Bruno Latour recently offered an additional referential to the Left/Right axis: terrestrial (i.e. grounded) and offshore (i.e. ungrounded)
final_comments_cp_1: discussing climate policy without explicit reference to policy mixes or governance is a bit uncomfortable. It orients towards theoretical potentials rather than actual design and implementation questions.

weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: citizens do not like it. they prefer incentives, without realizing that incentives are paid with taxes, and everybody pays them, also the poor not emitting much or without access to incentives
comments_2nd_order_1: scientist working on sustainability agree on that. however, technologists, who claim they work on sustainability, have often a a different view generated by their group identity. i worked on a lor of different technologies, from milk to fuel cells, from solar to cement, but mostly bioenergy. all the technologist think they work will save the world and the other technologies are 'adversaries'.
further_research: the most  important gap is the border taxation, but it will remain a gap as nobody know how to implement taxation at borders and the reaction of other countries.
final_comments_cp_1: please try to include other aspects of sustainability. fine to consider also social and economic aspects, but climate change is not the only threat to the inhabitability of the planet

I think it is better to ask directly: which policy package would you prefer?
comments_important_policies_1: I forgot to mention before: I think you do not cover all the policy options (i cannot go back to the questionnaire now). Actually, infrastructural investments, including in skills and retraining, are extremely important. But now I cannot mention this. So for me the best policy mix is: 1. buy coal and gas from exporter, to "store" it in democratic countries (and do not leave space for price manipulation to non-democratic exporters); 2. finance developing countries to preserve forests, with an enforcement system with trade premia (reductions in the tariffs to fruits and vegetables export) and sanctions (viceversa). 3. invest in the green infrastructure. 4. provide progressive adoption subsidies conditional on individual abatement targets.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: obvious, all textbook ones: good incentives to innovate, pollution, pays principles, revenues to offset the losers
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: in unregulated energy markets and with market power from exporters, the "price signal" can be inverted either by "green paradox" types of effects or more likely by further price increases, making the political acceptability of such policy even more difficult to reach. I think carbon prices can be very effective if: i. we have the good storage infrastructure so our dependency on exporters is relatively low; ii. long-term contracts are privileged to short-term contracts in energy markets; iii. redistribution mechanisms are clear and well-understood, to ensure acceptability.
further_research: The key issue is not the policy mix per se, but the sequence of policy interventions
final_comments_cp_1: Sorry, I gave the comments while I was answering. I hope they will be of help!
request_results_1: sure, it is very interesting and I am also working on these topics.

comments_1: It seems to me that climate policy has lost its way and is now a political movement based on faulty climate models. It does not seem to follow any of the scientific endeavours of Physicists and seems unable to escape from the alarmism of activists.
comments_policy_rank_1: The focus on emissions reduction assumes that "greenhouse gases" have an effect which will be reduced by doing so. This paper clearly shows it is not necessary to reduce emissions: Coe et al (2021) "The impact of CO2, H2O and other Greenhouse gasses on Equilibrium Earth Temperatures"; International Journal of Atmosphereic and Oceanic Sciences, 5(2): 29-40
comments_important_policies_1: It is not necessary to have a climate policy and it is foolish to think such a policy would have any effect on the climate. However, it would make citizens poorer and lead to energy povity and power outages as countries begin to rely on renewables instead of fossil fuels.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: It has nothing to commend it.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The value of CO2 can be determined to be a positive benefit for the environment. Increases in CO2 have led to greening of the planet and increased crop yields. Many of the supposed problems of climate change have not occurred and will not occur (see Research paper cited earlier).
further_research: I do not believe it is necessary to have carbon pricing or aim for net zero emissions.
comments_background_1: I do not have any political views. I find most political parties not relevant and not aware of scientific facts when it comes to climate issues.
final_comments_cp_1: The wording of the questions seems to assume that CO2 is the temperature/climate control dial and this is just not so. Therefore, I think this research questionnaire is not very useful.

comments_1: It is important to understand whether the policy is excessive to relevant stakeholders.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Easy to track and monitor carbon emission. Put a price on carbon emission which is essential in examining the enforceability of environmental regulation in a country.  We can expect to see the price is high in those countries where the environmental regulations are stringent and the reverse when the environmental regulations are lax.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Transparency/Data integrity/Hard for real-time tracking.
further_research: The ability to scale the carbon pricing (emission trading scheme) to the global scale. Emission reduction is a collective effort rather than country- or regional-specific. It is also important to understand the pollution haven hypothesis and whether the stringent environmental regulations in developed countries drive firms to move the entire production to other developing countries, hence reduce CO2 emission in the home country but increase the CO2 emission in the other countries (and the net CO2 emission may be even positive taking into account the transportation activities).

Cap trade is good for some sectors like electric power while carbon pricing is better to alter consumption preferences (eg: fossil fuels and livestock).  We need to see it as different wedges that will fill the gap. Also there is a need of funding novel enterprises that will generate income from carbon offset activities without depending (or partially depending) on carbon payments from Govts.
further_research: How revenue from carbon prices can be used for reaching net-zero goals needs to further investigated, which may actually reduce the carbon prices required to achieve the same.

comments_1: The timeframe of achieving results is also key: can the policies delivery the emissions reductions in a timely enough manner, while also being equitable? I see a tension between effectiveness and equity issues - the quicker the reductions are achieved, then the more effective a policy, but an equitable transition requires policy development processes that can take time.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Creates a cap on emissions, has an in-built sanctioning mechanism (of sorts) because companies would miss out on benefits, easy to adopt because it does not affect citizens so directly (behavior change in industry)
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: As a market, it is viable/vulnerable to economic shocks or crises, the final objective (reducing emissions) is lost in the market logic, effect is too little, too slow, it doesn't lead to rapid enough transformation
comments_2nd_order_1: The distribution is not even globally. There are more researchers in Europe paying attention to climate governance in general, and carbon pricing issues, than in other political science communities. Research based in the US found that a minimal proportion of political science and international relations scholar investigate climate governance issues in any form.
further_research: Equity issues are too neglected, including equity within a jurisdiction and across jurisdictions. Also the timeframe of effectiveness and degree of real transformation are areas of research still required.
comments_background_1: When it comes to left and right, the boxes of such ideologies are, I find quite inadequate when it comes to climate governance. Climate change should be an issue that concerns the entire of the political class to the same degree. The response should be both effective and equitable - this doesn't seem controversial, yet is often thrown into the box of 'left' ideology. however, it is the problem of climate change that dictates the required solution, and I find the left/right discussions become simply a distraction and a delaying tactic.
final_comments_cp_1: It would be interesting to include policy options that ban certain activities/resource use. E.g. banning fossil fuels altogether, banning fossil fuel cars, phasing out coal, banning finance of fossil projects - these are all realistic policy options that are currently being developed. Also, understanding the systemic nature of the transformational response required is an important aspect that discussions of carbon pricing should be able to identify (e.g. as a positive aspect of carbon pricing). Good luck with the interesting research!

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: High efficiency; more transparency of objectives and winners/losers; more clarity on achievable emissions reductions

further_research: The challenge of getting to zero emissions is a major one. Carbon pricing delivers immediate emissions reductions on the margin and can significantly alter the energy mix, but would it get us to zero? Maybe through reinvestments of the public revenue into zero carbon alternatives. But in terms of the pricing alone, prices would have to reach extremely high levels to get to zero emissions. There targeted, sectoral policies and mandates will be more effective.

Research_interests_1: energy and climate planning, spatial planning, institutional capacity
comments_1: I have been studying integration of climate change mitigation aspects into local spatial planning, and with the associated level of uncertainty, due to being at a strategic level, I find it very difficult if not impossible, to estimate how much certain strategies will contribute to reduced GHG emissions. It can, however, be qualitatively assessed, e.g. in relation to equity and synergies with other sustainability objectives.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: This is not something that I have studied, but of course  I find it important that financial incentives align with sustainable development. I have reflected upon whether a global cap and trade could be connected to a global carbon budget, where any excess emissions directly need to finance CCS options that has been scientifically proven to be working.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: If they do not align with global carbon budgets, or if any compensatory measures for offsets is ineffective, which most current carbon offsetting projects seem to be, they will not steer towards the required levels of reduction.
further_research: As mentioned earlier, it would be interesting to investigate whether global cap and trade could be connected to scientifically proven CCS technologies, still being in their infancy. If negative emissions still should be a part of future climate projections, it seems logical to let their high initial cost be a part of such a cap and trade system. Perhaps this has been studied (it is not my primary field of study).

comments_1: We are dangerously behind reducing global emissions.  To ensure rapid emissions reductions, it might be necessary to undertake some actions that are not least-cost, but the implications should not be regressive.
comments_policy_rank_1: In the first part, I assume 'adoption subsidies' is removing subsidies to high-carbon activities and instead subsidizing clean alternatives.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Targets the externality directly and allows the market to 'do the work' directly in reducing emissions.  It's a top-down comprehensive and therefore 'fair' strategy, when other sectoral policies are more piecemeal (and can allow for vested interests to push back - e.g. in shipping & aviation).
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: It's politically extremely complex as those involved in high-carbon activities will inevitably ask for support and exemptions (e.g. steel and cement, as well as power industry). Thus, it is still exposed to the issues related to more 'bottom-up' sectoral policies.
further_research: Communicating with the wider public. Researchers and policy-makers are in their own bubble. Unlike sectoral policies, it's very difficult to reach the general public on CP.  Work must be done to bridge the gap. Moreover, as much as the technical discussions around prices, coverage, etc., political economy challenges in implementation should be examined.
comments_background_1: Those on the 'right' are fewer but disproportionately powerful in many ways (political influence, legal expertise, lobbying and PR power, etc), which makes it very difficult for those with 'left-leaning' views to make progress on the climate and equity agenda. It's often like swimming against the current. Therefore, policy-makers must work to make incentives better-aligned to support these agendas and use behavioral psychology. (i.e. generate profit-making opportunities for clean technologies, somehow 'reward' polluting sector participants for cutting emissions, etc).
final_comments_cp_1: A lot of the earlier questions were too similar to be able to answer in a way that provides much information. I assume many of the answers will be similar, as many will feel the multiple choices provided were 'important' or 'very important'. Of course, the real answer in most cases is 'it depends' (on the cultural context, level of implementation of policy, level of development in a country etc). It would have been good to be able to go back to edit answers. It also seemed like the survey was trying to 'catch the participant by suprise' by not giving much information and not allowing to edit answers. But ultimately I think the results will be less informative as a consequence.

further_research: As I mentioned before, carbon pricing in food systems has a big problem of sketchy knowledge, particularly related to animal-sourced foods. No distinction is done among production systems and the baseline emissions in livestock-abandoned ecosystems is ignored.

comments_1: Beyond "feasibility" is process. More deliberative forms of democracy whereby citizens are more empowered to inform climate policy are crucial both for fairness of process, and in order to bring about shared ownership of policies which could be seen as less feasible when imposed without citizen engagement.
comments_policy_rank_1: Many of these policies could work well. Effectiveness, efficiency, equity, and feasibility will all depend on how policies are designed. Many of these are not alternatives but complementary policies. Eg. innovation support is required to develop new techs, but making a technology widespread and affordable will often require support in scaling up. Policies like carbon tax are likely to force economies away from emissive technologies ("sticks") in tandem with policies to encourage low carbon techs ("carrots").
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Directly taxes GHG emissions, in principle could directly incentivize GHG emissions reductions. Taxes could be ring-fenced to fund low carbon transformation. Important as part of a suite of policies to transform economies and energy systems.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: In practice these have often been implemented at levels which are insufficient to drive substantial change, equity is a challenge, accounting can be a challenge (eg. do producers or users of fossil fuels pay?). Doesn't address market failures and broader societal challenges.
comments_cp_statements1_1: Generation of public revenues isn't unique to carbon pricing, but could be an important factor. Wrt consumers' being more influenced by prices than by environmental concerns, I question the premise of "stealth strategies" alone for climate, and think broader engagement of the public would be beneficial for effective strategies.
further_research: Not directly on carbon pricing, but I think work on the democratic challenge of climate change, eg. Rebecca Willis's "Too Hot To Handle", could be relevant on design of effective climate policy.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing inures to the benefits of the low carbon economies when the Carbon emitting countries pay for the emissions in a trade-off fashion to off-set the imbalances and disadvantages and undue advantages of the low and advanced economies respectively.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The set back in this approach therefore is a Kuznet tendencies of over-pollution and payment in the long-run which eventually erodes the gains of the subsidies advanced to the low carbon economies. they become worse off in terms of their efforts to remain 'green' as their economies will be dependent on the support of the advances economies for survival; a phenomenon that can jeopardise the economic development of the low economy.
further_research: Since most consumers put emphasis on the prices of a commodity other than the environmental safeguards, it is imperative to assess the perception and knowledge base of consumers about the Carbon pricing and its implication on environmental and economic safeguards of an economy.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: As Nordhaus first demonstrated carbon pricing is quantifiable via  integrated assessment modelling, and so delivers optimal properties. The British Columbia example shows the practical viability and feasability of carbon pricing.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Compared with other approaches, very few weaknesses.
comments_cp_statements1_1: For maximum effect carbon pricing should be based on houshold rebates, exactly as championed by David Wilson the first early proponent of the concept of energy-use fees.
comments_2nd_order_1: Sadly the magic of Pigouvian economics remains a mystery to many.
further_research: The key metric of the social cost of carbon dominates, any research that helps pin down this crucial parameter is well worthwhile.

Research_interests_1: theories of transformation, theories of the state, democratic theory
comments_1: By disruptiveness I mean the measure's capacity to eliminate a high-carbon or otherwise destructive economic practice or complex of practices very quickly, without consideration of policy coherence or economic consequences. An example would be the banning of soybean and palmoil imports without consideration of WTO and other legal and economic constraints.
comments_policy_rank_1: The problem is that some of the measures will not achieve their objectives at all (information provision, innovation support, perhaps also carbon taxes), if the objective is to achieve the Paris goals. It is difficult to judge the efficiency and equity of measures that are completely ineffective. If you mean efficiency despite ineffectiveness, then yes, they are efficient because they do not hurt anyone, but they have no effect either.
important_policies_7_SP: Disruptive regulation in terms of a 'creative destruction'
comments_important_policies_1: Disruptive regulation means that we need to close doors in order for other doors to open up. Just to open doors (innovation, adoption subsidies, market choice) means that we create more and more niches but do not force the destructive pathways to get closed down. Once they are closed, the niches will necessarily become the new mainstream. There is no other way, I believe.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing works as an economic incentive. Given sustainable alternatives, it may have some effect in getting the energy transition (and mobility transition) going.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: As an instrument it is not strong enough to decarbonize as radically and quickly as is necessary. It keeps within the logic of growth and technological innovation, which is not sufficient to spur a comprehensive socio-metabolic transition. It may have socially disruptive effects unless compensated in an ecological tax reform that has considerable rebound-effects.
comments_cp_statements1_1: My answers above are somewhat erratic, as I believe that it all depends on how rigorous carbon pricing is: just adding a few cents costs on fuels does not change consumer behaviour. Doubling or tripling the price of a liter of fuel does. But this is without the scope of most schemes discussed and politically barely feasible.
comments_2nd_order_1: Just a gut feeling - I have honestly no idea. Carbon pricing seems to be a mantra of wisdom in lack of politically feasible alternatives.
further_research: not an expert on this
comments_background_1: Economic growth is important to stabilise the democratic order. That is the main problem. Wealth could be distributed without growth, and people might even have a higher life satisfaction. the problem is that a non-growing institutional order must either be 'religious' and authoritarian or highly instable, as far as we know. We are in a trap.
final_comments_cp_1: Being a social and political theorist, my expertise on individual climate policies is limited. I hope I could provide some useful input nevertheless.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: They create a level playing field. They influence end-user choices.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Either must be accompanied by revenue re-distribution toward those least able to modify their behavior, e.g. persons inadequately served by public transport, those with low incomes, etc. Such redistribution is essential but is resisted politically, and renders a carbon tax or cap-and-trade difficult to institute.
further_research: In places where carbon pricing has been operating for some time, we need to understand how this was introduced and made politically acceptable. We must learn from those jurisdictions where carbon pricing is working. We also need better ways of informing those in the public who fear carbon pricing, letting them know more about the compensating improvements in their lives (such as more frequent, safe, clean public transport, or direct income subsidies). We need to inform leadership of the positive accompanying policies that must be introduced along with carbon pricing.

Perhaps the gap is understanding how effective this measure is compared to the preservation and conservation of natural ecosystems (this may exist but I am unaware of such research).

Research_interests_1: participatory, social-ecological systems, landscapes, agroforestry, ecosystem services
comments_1: Climate policy instruments should stand the test of time.  The problem with policies is that it takes a longer time for it to be created and/or amended. Hence, it is important that there is a level of flexibility to the policy that would allow it to be re-adapted to the emerging sustainability challenges without the need to undergo an excessively lengthy policy cycle.
comments_important_policies_1: Climate risks could have very different impacts across scales (i.e., town to nation). Hence, it is important that innovations are supported to develop technologies, practices, or systems that is appropriate to the various social-ecological conditions across scales. This should also be coupled with participatory processes to create more holistic climate policies that reduce trade-offs among stakeholders. Participatory instruments also allow for these policies to be accepted and legitimized across sectors.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing provides a tangible economic framework for a specific scale (e.g., town, province, nation) on limiting their emission.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing favors entities (e.g., companies, offices) that are larger and have better financial capital as these have better buffer to pay for additional costs. This widens the inequality gap in the economic sector. Existing inequality among social classes might also be exacerbated (e.g., prices of products might increase due to additional taxes producers have to pay, leaving those in the lower social classes at a disadvantage).
comments_cp_statements1_1: I think the scale at which carbon pricing is implemented will have varied results. For example, local governments versus national governments implementing carbon pricing might see different results.
comments_2nd_order_1: Carbon pricing is quite a sensitive topic for developing countries as it is seen as a driver that furthers inequality and impedes development.
further_research: Understanding the impacts of carbon pricing across scales and identifying the "winners" and "losers". Carbon pricing should be framed in the context of "panarchy" where its embedded impacts affect scales, larger or smaller, thereby producing more tradeoffs and/or synergies.

criteria_5_SP: political sustainability -- see Barry Rabe's book
comments_1: Research which helps navigate the policy dialogue to any set of policies which reduce GHG emissions is essential.  The problem is that the set of policies which are sustainable are often insufficient to provide meaningful levels of mitigation.  Having worked on this problem for nearly 40 years, I'm pessimistic.
comments_policy_rank_1: Noise to signal ratio on my responses here is very high.
comments_important_policies_1: I'm a "greenwashing skeptic".  We need to distinguish between policies which provide tangible outcomes (i.e., lower emissions) and those which simply make people feel better about themselves.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: If GHG taxes can become part of the accepted social contract for supporting government provision of public goods (education, infrastructure, defense, etc.), there is the possibility that such policies could become sustainable.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Barry Rabe's book (Can we tax carbon?) documents the track record of climate policy measures in the democratic arena.  These policies typically do not last.  Voters want to see tangible results, and the public goods produced by carbon taxes are not realized contemporaneously.
further_research: Many observers fail to account for the substantial lag between costs and benefits associated with carbon pricing.  Can we sell voters on policies which raise energy prices in the near term in order to reduce temperatures and storm damages for our grandchildren?  This is probably a hard sell.
final_comments_cp_1: Nicely structured.  Thanks for doing this.

comments_1: Financial incentives will be key, at least at the outset.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Those who burn more fossil fuels pay for doing so. This provides an incentive for them to innovate and cut costs.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Increases the price of products and possibly services, and price hikes are passed on to the consumers and the public at large.
further_research: The largest gaps in the current research is an inability to understand completely the domino effects of carbon pricing within the economic system. This reflects a lack of knowledge how increasing prices for goods and services effects national economies as well as consumers on the ground. Simulation modeling can address some of these concerns and avoid costly mistakes.
comments_background_1: I am a pragmatic political animal with a strong social and environmental conscience. Good leadership will be essential if we are to reverse the current trends in global climate change.
final_comments_cp_1: Interesting survey. Of course, as you know, there are many alternative policy mechanisms that can be employed to reduce GHGs, and they all should be considered. The real challenge, which is not addressed in your survey, is what combination is best for each nation and also globally that will reduce GHG emissions at the least cost possible.

Research_interests_1: Renewable energy, reconciliation, climate change mitigation, human rights
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: General feedback is that Carbon pricing schemes can be effective but it does depend largely on their design and the two forms of carbon pricing can work together. Carbon tax: creates revenue for governments, can encourage R&D spending re renewable energy, may be able to influence the decisions of energy users, creates an incentive for companies to go green, can be an effective mitigation strategy. Can be effective at influencing decisions of companies as well if the price of the tax is high enough that it can’t be easily passed on to consumers. Cap-and-trade: Is good because it creates a total cap on fossil fuel emissions - there will be a finite limit. This can take less time to develop potentially than a carbon tax and it can lead to faster cuts in pollution. This creates government revenue because the credits for carpentry can be auctioned off and the government can control the system. Companies may purchase credits to ensure that they have enough in case they need to match a certain amount of greenhouse gases, but then they may actually find that they do not need to use them and can retire the products. Since there is a finite level of emissions permitted within a cabin trade system the retiring of such credits would basically create a lower. Those credits would not go back into an auction or be traded to another company necessarily, they can be fully retired such that no fossil fuels allocated to that credit are emitted.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Both systems create more costs for companies which can and likely will be passed on at least to some degree to consumers. Carbon tax: Carbon taxes can be very resource intensive and time intensive to develop. In a Federalist country like Canada, there can be litigation that ensues over a federal government imposing a requirement to develop a carbon tax and each province and if different states within the same country are given flexibility to design their own carbon tax scheme then there can be a variation of programs across the nation which will not necessarily complement one another and may have varying degrees of efficiency. There is no cap on the amount of emissions that are permitted; as long as individuals and/or companies can afford to pay the price, they will be able to continue on without adjusting their energy consumption behaviors at all. The carbon tax may create an incentive for companies to relocate their head offices to avoid taxes - carbon tax schemes would need to take this into account. Can have devastating effects for low-middle class people and members of vulnerable groups. Designing exemption programs can be very complex and will be controlled by governments that may not do a good job at ensuring vulnerable peoples are not impacted by the tax. This is an issue in Canada with exemptions for Indigenous Peoples.
comments_2nd_order_1: Such a difficult thing to estimate especially considering many environmental lawyers will be employed by fossil fuel dependent companies and I do not know the proportion of lawyers that are employed by companies versus those defending the environment.
further_research: - effectiveness and stringency of different designs of carbon pricing schemes could be further evaluated so that countries without carbon pricing in place could benefit from guidelines and best practices as well as case studies that demonstrate success. - research on how best to approach exemptions for vulnerable groups (especially Indigenous Peoples and communities) from carbon taxes and whether such exemptions will adversely impact gag reductions efforts would be very helpful. Some states may be hesitant to provide exemptions and the rationale is they fear it will be contrary to their efforts but I believe this to be untrue. More research is needed to demonstrate that carbon pricing can still function well and achieve the desired outcomes even while ensuring the most vulnerable aren’t impacted. - research on revenue recycling and uses of proceeds from carbon pricing would be helpful as well in order to further support whether this has an impact on R&D or if companies/families who receive rebates etc are likely to actually use this revenue to go green

comments_1: Feasibility in many countries is heavily shaped by political economy considerations.
comments_policy_rank_1: My responses relate to these policies as I have seen them implemented in practice, rather than their theoretical merits. In particular, many cap-and-trade schemes have large loopholes and elements of compensation that are hard to justify.
comments_important_policies_1: Carbon tax and cap-and-trade are substitutes, so this is response is more of a preference a ranking. Of course, it is possible to apply cap-and-trade to some emissions and a carbon tax to others. R&D subsidies are extremely important for countries that are large and near the global technology frontier. Less so for others. I specifically added applied public research funding (for climate-relevant research) because many countries have much lower levels of public research funding generally than is likely to be economically optimal and/or direct funding towards objectives that are unsupportive of or even conflicting with climate mitigation and adaptation.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: The main strength of carbon pricing is that it can provide a uniform carbon price that applies to all emissions-generating activities in an economy with modest costs for implementation and compliance activities.  In contrast, directly regulating these activities would inevitably generate large variation in shadow carbon prices across activities and would require a huge bureaucracy. While the question presumably refers to a domestic carbon price, it is also possible to put a price on carbon-intensive imports. This was previously seen as a (possibly) theoretically desirable but (likely) politically impractical measure to avoid international emissions leakage. However, it seems likely such measures could now be implemented by large countries/blocs like the US, EU and China, not only for the stated purpose of limiting leakage, but to economically coerce recalcitrant governments (e.g. Australia) to take domestic policy actions.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The key advantage of domestic carbon pricing over regulation in developed countries that do not already have such a price has probably been lost at this point. In countries like Australia, it is almost impossible to conceive of any policy involving an obvious carbon price mechanism being politically feasible, as a result of misinformation propagated during past vitriolic debates. Moreover, given how far the price of renewable electricity and even electric vehicle and battery technologies has fallen, the excess economic costs of directly regulating technologies in these sectors is probably modest.
further_research: While a lot of work has been done on carbon border adjustments (and the like), I think more economic, legal and international political economy research is needed on practical policy instruments of this sort.

comments_policy_rank_1: The carbon tax without corrective measures is very regressive, but there can be redistribute measures added post hoc, so that question is tricky. We've been doing that for 40 years with no gains. It's great to support innovation, unless it's for things like CCUS or other false solutions. They don't give a clear signal to fossil fuel industries that their time is up!

Research_interests_1: Energy economics; environmental economics; climate change policies
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: carbon pricing is the first-best policy instrument: putting a price on the negative externality. Carbon pricing done right can also be equitable (revenue neutral carbon-fee-and-dividend approach) and stimulate innovation (predictable return on investment)
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Political opposition to anything that looks like a tax is strong in certain jurisdictions, even though it is economically superior to command-and-control interventions or poorly-targeted subsidies. Cap-and-trade is often focused on industries rather than broadly all carbon-emitting sources (including households and transportation).
comments_cp_statements1_1: answer (j) about the double-dividend: making carbon pricing revenue neutral and addressing equity concerns is more important than using revenue for other purposes.
comments_2nd_order_1: Economists see carbon pricing as the first-pest policy on efficiency grounds. Thus it is our top choice as a policy instruments, although there are trade-offs among the different market-based approaches.
further_research: Knowledge gaps in this area are often related to assessing the impact of carbon pricing on equity (distributional outcomes) and innovation (dynamic outcomes).

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: With carbon pricing you get equal marginal abatement costs for all regulated actors so it's the first-best policy. Carbon pricing adheres to the polluter-pays principle and there's a certain elegance to it as well. Also it seems to work in many cases, such as in the EU ETS.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing is quite tricky to implement in some sectors, such as forestry and land-use. Also it's not exactly easy to explain to some parts of the public ("the firms can continue to pollute if they just pay"). The main problem is setting the ambition level, both in the scientific sense (what is the correct price level?) and politically (strong lobbying against less free allowances).
