Research_interests_1: Energy, buildings, heating, cooling, efficiency, thermal, heat networks
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Provides harmonized mechanism for accounting for emissions across different industries, in theory allowing market incentives pick out the most cost effective solutions.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Fails to account for the significant differences between sectors in terms of the specific challenges for decarbonization. Therefore they cannot address specific barriers (e.g. in buildings, often efficiency improvements are already cost effective but not implemented for other reasons). They can also place unfair cost burdens (e.g. In the residential sector, often the buildings in worst condition are occupied by people with lowest income)
comments_2nd_order_1: I think it's considered a good thing in general, but at a recent building efficiency conference I attended there were almost no mentions of carbon pricing.
further_research: I think the relative impact on carbon prices on people of different income levels, locations, or sociodemographic groups (e.g. young adults, parents with children) is not well understood. The ability of different people to respond to price signals is very different (e.g. a rural family has different options available to them than an urban student)

Research_interests_1: meat consumption, plant-based diets, sociology of consumption, sustainble consumption, food studies
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: It can steer the market so that implementing some of the (less favored) climate regulation might be avoided.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Pricing in itself does not guarantee decrease in carbon emissions if demand remains high in the market for things that cause emissions, and if reasonable alternative products with less carbon emissions (and with competitive pricing) are not available. Further, the situation might be particularly unfair for those consumers with less spending power.
comments_cp_statements1_1: For the question j): Subsidies have the same effect as well. Further, one can also argue that placing regulation on emissions preserves our ecosystem services and public health, among other things, and can be seen as highly valuable also economically. So it is more of a matter of effectiveness of the measure from this perspective that also tells how important it can be economically.
further_research: There is probably a lot of work in calculating reliable numbers for different products concerning the amount of emissions they produce during their lifetime and how to create pricing systems and certificates that are perceived as reliable and acceptable by the various actors of the system. I am also concerned how the question of biodiversity loss could be tackled in this context so that the carbon perspective would not solely dominate the discussion of environmental threats in the public sphere. In other words, it is one essential thing to be able to create a system where carbon emissions would steer the price of the products, but this should be combined with the products' effects on biodiversity, so that  focusing on carbon would not create a mental picture that the environmental issues have been solved with focusing on it.

comments_1: Another important criteria to assess CP instruments is how well they fit to local - regional conditions or needs.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: The carbon tax or cap and trade policies might call the attention or awareness of those sources of emission (enterprises, industries, countries, etc.) toward the importance of emissions reduction or alleviation of their impact on climate change.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Such a policy implies that reduction of emissions is not an issue as long as you pay for it. The final implication is that reduction of emissions does not occur, since the sources have a mechanism of payment ot trade to allow them to maintain certain level of emissions. Overall, the emissions are not reduced, rather their effects are transferred to somewhere or someone else.
further_research: Determination of local - regional baselines for carbon sequestration and pricing in forests. Definition of appropriate mechanisms of compensation to owners for carbon sequestration in forests. Assessment of innovative strategies to foster carbon cap and trade in forestry. Determination of geographic areas with higher potential for carbon cap and trade.
final_comments_cp_1: I really hope that this survey, and my answers, are usefull to promote better policy instruments in the process of reversing or mitigating climate change.

Research_interests_1: climate finance, sustainable finance, financial regulation, climate policy
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: - Cap and trade only: has a total (carbon credits) budget that can be controlled, therefore being more manageable; - Numeric and therefore easier to calculate ("evidence") and add to balance sheets; - For economic/financial actors: economiccentric solution ("pricing externalities"), which can be/is used to theoretically exempt economic/financial actors from responsibility, which is shifted to governments (for building up and implementing the policy);
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Complex (costly) new public structures/mechanisms; often regressive, with higher impacts on lower income levels; - High potential of overall public opposition; - They're easy input data as "liabilities" or risks (costs), making the negatives clear and strengthening counter-narratives around competitiveness and carbon leakage; -  Easier opposition by specific lobbies in their entirety or during the creation of exemptions/exceptions and varying implementation degrees (price oscillation/categories); - Carbon pricing only sends a non-time-bound signal (i.e. an action with hope) that assumes that (a) all negative climate externalities have been appropriately priced and (b) economic agents will react with positive climate action (and not with tax evasion, headquarters relocation, climate-negative innovation) etc. Therefore, it cannot clearly define decarbonization effectiveness beyond multiple-assumptions models.
further_research: Equity issues (incl. in historical terms - i.e. how has carbon pricing been received by populations in different countries throughout history); voluntary and/or self-reporting nature of emissions' reporting by companies; does decarbonization follow expected/projected speed following the implementation of carbon pricing (i.e. what happens if we don't consider that individual agents - incl. consumers - are rational and markets are in equilibrium); how do investments/financial flows react to carbon pricing in the short and long term for specific countries and sectors.
comments_background_1: Libertarian left (both political and economic).
final_comments_cp_1: Eager to see the results of the research.

Research_interests_1: sustainability management; climate mitigation; cross-sector partnerships
equity_7_SP: it all in the design for all of these
comments_policy_rank_1: Regulations and market-based instruments can be designed to make them more effective, more equitable and more feasible. My answers on many of these are "it depends on the design"
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Putting a price on carbon sends the appropriate price signals to the producer/consumer.  It makes the substitutes more economical and drives behavior towards the low/zero carbon options.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Administrative burden and importance of considering equity for low income citizens.
comments_cp_statements1_1: I don't like the framing of regulation or market-based instruments. We need all the tools the address the urgency of the climate emergency.
comments_2nd_order_1: If I take my broader field - Management - then generally there is support for market-based instruments over regulation. But sustainability management scholars 100% support a price on carbon. Some business scholars would not support any climate policy, unfortunately.
further_research: In general, there is a strong need to address carbon accounting to ensure consistent measurement, scoping, disclosure, assurance and transparency. Relatedly, there is a need to improve organizational level net-zero planning and implementation. So research areas related to carbon accounting, carbon finance, carbon disclosure, carbon reporting, climate action plan implementation, embedding climate into decision-making processes ... these are all key questions for management scholars (e.g., strategy, finance, accounting disciplines).
comments_background_1: Your framing of economy versus the environment and North versus South is inaccurate (in my view). We all need to transition to net-zero emissions, but that does not mean it is at the expense of the economy or other parts of the world. That is a framing from 1992, not 2021. And it is a framing that was related to resources more generally, not climate specifically. There are many substitutions that will enable no or low carbon options (e.g., plant based diets; zero-emission vehicles; renewable energy; etc.). Also, our product lifecycle is so global now, that production versus consumption emissions vary drastically.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Efficiency, revenue generation, possibility to use the revenue to address distributional issues
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Weak support from the public if it leads to a high price hike in the economy. In most countries, consumers are not ready yet to face the consequences of a carbon pricing that aims at an ambitious carbon emissions reduction. The only feasible and sustainable solution to reducing emissions in the long run is a policy that would promote innovation to reduce the dependence to fossil energy. Without a good substitute to fossil energy, all the market-based policy instruments will fail (with a high probability) because of an absence of social support if they do not lead to innovation that decouples growth and fossil energy.

Research_interests_1: climate change mitigation, scenarios, climate policy, economics, technological transitions
comments_policy_rank_1: The economic efficiency of some policy options (direct regulation, subsidies, innovation) depends highly on how they are targeted. It's therefore impossible to judge them on a general level.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Both provide economic incentives and therefore should be good in terms of economic efficiency. It might be politically more easy to adjust the emission cap to a desired level, which can be based e.g. on UNFCC targets and long-term scenarios.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Taxation is always politically delicate subject. Policy-makers might be unwilling to set the tax very high to drive the emissions sufficiently down. The 'correct level' of an emission tax is hugely debatable, and the research literature for the social cost of carbon includes anything from near-zero to serval hundreds of dollars per tonne.
comments_cp_statements1_1: Question h): harmonizing taxation globally seems to be extremely difficult, so I think people talking about 'a globally uniform carbon tax' have very limited understanding of how international politics and climate policy actually work.
comments_2nd_order_1: There is a certain undertone in all of the questions. Sounds like someone has a bias towards pricing things.
further_research: Given all the complications that real life has, as compared to stylized economic theories, how much pricing actually affects consumers' and companies' decisions? This should be differentiated between short-term and long-term.

comments_policy_rank_1: My answers depend on whether effectiveness is evaluated in the short- or long-term. E.g., in the long-run, eco-label might work well, but in the short-run, carbon tax is more effective.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: It is immediately effective and coercive.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: It is politically contentious.
further_research: The role of unintended consequences of carbon pricing in relation to adaptation.
comments_background_1: It would have been interesting to add the GAL/TAN dimension here, which is cross-cutting the L-R dimension, and appears relevant to your research.
final_comments_cp_1: Good luck!

equity_7_SP: Carbon Tax or Cap-and-trade with per capita revenue receycling

comments_policy_rank_1: In my opinion, it makes a very important difference whether one considers "pure" market or price based instrument (like a carbon tax or a Cap-and-trade system) or the "relevant" implementation option, i.e. the composite approach of a market based instrument in combination with an appropriate revenue redistribution to shift the distributional impact from regressive to progressive (or at least to distribution neutrality)
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: - generates government revenue (as opposed to standards and regulations) that can be used to target unintended distributional effects (which standards and regulations also have, by the way, just not as visible and therefore less salient to policymakers and the public). - In contrast to regulation by regulatory law, a comparatively low need for information on the part of policymakers/regulators. - not only needs comparatively little information, but even generates additional information (among other things, disclosure of marginal abatement costs).
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: - regressive distributional effect, at least insofar as this is not neutralized by adequate use of the revenues or even turned into its opposite, i.e. a progressive distributional effect. - can, of course, only fully develop the intended adaptation effect if corresponding action alternatives can also be implemented, for example through the (public) infrastructure. CO2 pricing for individual transport only really makes sense if well-developed public local and long-distance transport is available as an alternative. - quite difficult to understand for policy-makers and especially the public. -  "easy victim" for targeted distortions and misinformation.
further_research: How can public knowledge and awareness of the unique advantages of carbon pricing be raised quickly and in such a manner, that the chances of widespread adoption and implementation of this uniquely powerful and scalable policy instrument are significantly improved
final_comments_cp_1: We are obviously working in the same domain and most, if not all of the questions you raised in the survey, are also part of my work/ the work of the research group on "Sustainability and Governance" that I lead at RWI - Leibniz Institute for Economic Research in Germany (Berlin Office), Web: https://en.rwi-essen.de/forschung-und-beratung/nachhaltigkeit-und-governance/. Perhaps, there is scope and occasion for one or another form of cooperation in the future? If this is something you can imagine, I would be happy to hear from you. E-Mail: Nils.ausdemMoore@rwi-essen.de

comments_policy_rank_1: Public investment in key sustainable infrastructures induce change on the economic organization of economic agents and therefore  can prove being essential in a low-carbon transition
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Cost-effective policy. Easy to implement by putting carbon tax on the source of energy (for industry and agriculture, more tricky to control and implement)
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Income regressive, low short-term elasticities and public impopularity. Carbon tax by itself can be sustained as the central driver of capital replacement, it has to be supported by complementarities policies such as income transfers, adoption subsidies to certain categories of households (not only income-based, but more regarding with their car use (constrained or not)
further_research: as economists, carbon pricing is  seen as the silver bullet from public intervention on the climate change issue. However the theoretical simplicity of the main idea coined by Pigou appears more complex when facing the real world, where the heterogeneity of situations and life-styles induces a massive redistributive shock. The question of how to address this heterogeneity in the instrument design is key to its effective implementation, and tends toward a second-best solution (the cost-efficiency  being lowered by the compensation measures required to its implementation). For this reason, in my opinion, carbon pricing should be oriented toward firms through a cap-and-trade, a carbon floor on energy products can be integrated for households, but the bulk of public policies designed for them shall more focus on emissions and energy standards, adoption subsidies for energy devices (cars, heating system, building retrofit...) and public investment to shape the cities and the spatial organization compatible with a low-carbon economy

Research_interests_1: energy policy, energy poverty, energy security
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: The theoretical strength of course is in internalizing the negative environmental externalities of carbon emissions and thereby sending the appropriate price signals to the market and allowing the market to adjust on its own, thus avoiding direct regulation or other potentially more costly policies.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: If not set properly, their effectiveness is highly debatable, and that seems to have been the case in some examples of their application to date. Also, while the market may in theory adjust to these price signals, subsidies (direct and indirect) e.g. for fossil fuels should also be removed, while the power of fossil fuel lobby can undermine the effectiveness of these initiatives. Finally, such market-based policies can have regressive distributional effects, shifting the additional cost onto consumers, with especially poorer consumers feeling the impacts of price increases the most.
further_research: Analysis of distributive effects, true effectiveness relative to other measures

comments_1: Such criteria are often portrayed as a multi-factor "dilemma" (e.g. energy trilemma of sustainability/security/cost). I think this is misleading. Better to frame as a hierarchy (somewhat analogous to the Maslow hierarchy).
efficiency_7_SP: "Cap and share" (TEQs, fee and dividend etc.) etc.) potentially outperform all other options
equity_7_SP: "Cap and share" (TEQs, fee and dividend etc.) etc.) potentially outperform all other options
comments_important_policies_1: "Carbon pricing" and "carbon tax" are very distinct concepts;  it would be better to pull out more that nuance. A more general point is that the success of ALL of the instruments mentioned is entirely dependent on society-wide grasp of the scale and urgency of the planetary crisis. This goes far far beyond the notion of "information provision".
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Pricing interventions may allow for flexible and innovative responses, and minimise incursions on both personal and corporate "freedoms" - consistent with meeting strict mitigation goals (strict, declining, emissions caps, consistent with fair shares of global budgets aligned with Paris temperature goals.).
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Pricing may exacerbate inequity, though this is not inevitable - e.g., cap-and share, TEQs etc. Market design interventions are always vulnerable to corruption and regulatory capture: corporations are generally much more powerful than individuals in influencing market designs and in rapid exploitation of market weaknesses.
comments_cp_statements1_1: Whether carbon pricing generates "public revenues" depends on the detailed design of the market intervention.
comments_2nd_order_1: Engineering research tends to focus on "direct" cost minimisation, i.e., independent of market interventions to price externalities. This provides a palette of technology options that can be considered in responding dynamically to whatever actual market prices arise.
further_research: There is a particular problem in extending carbon pricing to non-CO2 climate pollutants, especially methane. If pricing is limited to CO2 only, there may be perverse effects in excluding what would be effective interventions on non-CO2. But if non-CO2 is included on the de facto CO2eq (GWP100) basis it is well established that this may very poorly reflect relative climate outcomes. Separate, but related, carbon pricing that is fungible between fossil fuel CO2 and land use CO2 is problematic due to wildly different degrees of monitoring and verification of effects. Similarly (and somewhat overlapping) fungibility of pricing between CO2 emissions and removals from atmosphere may be problematic due to asymmetrical physical effects on the climate system (at least beyond global "net zero") and high variability in the permanence of purported removals.
comments_background_1: Most of my research career has been in interdisciplinary complex systems; but it is only in the last 10 years that I have applied this in the specific context of the planetary ecological emergency.

Research_interests_1: energy policy, transport, e-mobility, carbon pricing
comments_1: In my opinion there must be a just transition to a sustainable future - or there will be no transition, just a biz-as-usal march towards more and more horrible disasters
comments_policy_rank_1: There must be very strong redistribution mechanisms connected to the carbon tax, otherwise you get yellow vests. This separation in effictivity, efficiency, equity and feasiblity is wrong, because all measures that have any *significant* impact on emissions, or degradation of bio-diversity implies changes in incomes/life-styles and must have political support in order to be implemented, so efficiency etc. is totally dependendt on the policies being regarded by "the many" as just, will probably be hated by "the few".
comments_important_policies_1: I give cap and trade a low score, since the ruling elites always go for cap and trade in order to avoid haveing a high carbon price, because a high carbon price (w/o redistribution) is politically impossible - as the yellow vests  showed.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: prices are crucial in a profit maximising economy, changes behavior in the whole system.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: All existing carbon tax and cap&trade are w/o redistribution mechanisms (besides "something" in Canada).
comments_2nd_order_1: Regrettably , among EE economists carbon pricing is associated with the intented dysfunctionality of EU ETS, Chinese ETS, CDM - in addtion to being - without strong redistribution mechanisms socially unjust, so neoclassical carbon prising is correctly critized and opposed. This is tragic since it leads to a rejection of carbon pricing with strong redistribution mechanisms = direct, monthly cash payments to citizens.
further_research: a) The need for (re)distribution mechanism. b) Getting data for carbon content analysis of goods and services. The transaction data among firms is what is needed, to build national accounts from micro data, containing all flows of carbon (and other pollutants). That would make LCAs 100 times more precise  and open up for rational, knowledge based policy making, especially Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanisms.
comments_background_1: Politically I belong the "hard left" (l'extreme gauche), but the hard left is completely politically paralyzed. When Macron increased the price of carbon "they" (no me) had nothing to say. Higher prices would bring emissions down, but was socially unjust, but since they were/are strongly opposed to a progressive, just carbon tax, a tax with strong redistribution of carbon tax revenues, they had nothing to offer politically to the yellow vests. So they were/are silent on the sidelines when it comes to the carbon price.
final_comments_cp_1: Not bad, but a/THE question of combining a carbon tax with redistribution is not part of the survey, as it should be, given that is implemented in Canada, has twice been a "ballot proposal " in Washington state, is mentioned/discussed in the Stern/Stiglitz report on carbon pricing etc. Now you will find a lot of center-right wing economists being in favour of socially unjust carbon pricing - and too many caring about social justice being against it and then favouring other policy measures that are not so efficient, like subsidies and regulation. There are of course all sorts of regulations - and some of them are very efficient. All of them have "indirect" prices. A ban - is the same as a prohibitively hight price.

further_research: Accounting methodology (notably lifecycle emissions). How industrial synergies can help achieve the common targets.

Research_interests_1: climate change behavior, behavioral economics, decisions under risk, information framing
criteria_5_SP: Dynamic effects on behavior, cultural change, infrastructure, and technology development
comments_1: Framing effectiveness as certainty and degree of emissions reductions groups two criteria together that can move in opposite directions. Some policies may lead to large reductions in emissions but have lower levels of certainty (i.e. high risk, high reward) and vice versa.
important_policies_7_SP: Adaptation and mitigation of economic impacts to front line communities (those affected by climate impacts and sustainable transitions). And transportation policy!!
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: The critical strength of carbon pricing, if implemented broadly, is that it helps to drive reductions in emissions from all potential sources and incentive all potential sinks, unlike more piecemeal approaches. As an economist, I have always touted the importance of the efficiency of carbon pricing, but at this point, finding the lowest cost reductions first matters less than it did decades ago when we had time to slowly ramp down emissions. At this point, that key strength matters less because we need emissions to drop off a cliff, not down a ramp.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The equity impacts of carbon pricing are a huge problem. Given the historical failure of the redistribution of welfare gains from efficient but inequitable policies, I am skeptical that new policies will move far enough in recycling revenues back to low-income households. The other issue is that we cannot keep waiting around for political feasibility to come around. If it isn't politically feasible now, then forget it, move on, and circle back if circumstances change. But carbon pricing has taken up too much of the oxygen in climate policy compared to other approaches that are more politically feasible and socioeconomically equitable.
comments_cp_statements1_1: On i), while it isn't clear that it performs worse against all other instruments, the lack of salience of long-term energy costs in household appliance investments (for example) mean that higher minimum standards and higher energy star (or other simple labeling schemes) perform better than carbon pricing.
further_research: It may be my lack of familiarity, but I'm not sure we understand how carbon pricing affects long-time-horizon decisions like where to move (trading off commute costs) and how to design or invest in sustainable communities (e.g., sprawl) and transportation systems. We also do not know how higher energy prices through carbon pricing may drive individual support for climate mitigation and policymakers who implement such policies. I could envision an important short-term backlash effect that could cause serious setbacks in climate policy. This is already occurring in the fake-news universe for President Biden.

criteria_5_SP: Robustness of policy to also be resilient to (already locked in) climate impacts, this includes cross-resource/sustainability intdicator impacts

weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The need for political unity over large (preferable global) geographical and jurisdictional areas. Otherwise the effectiveness is limited and may have redistributional, carbon leakage effects...
further_research: Feasibility and rebound effects.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Enforcing a specific financial/emission boundary stimulates stakeholders to invest in a climate mitigation agenda.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: This instrument doesn't stimulate investment in a climate adaptation agenda. It also enforces a change, which creates risk for regression as it might not be an culturally internalized change yet.
further_research: Difficult to determine what products/services need to be included in carbon pricing. Also to determine what price is high enough to achieve successful transition to more sustainable behavior. Also to determine what carbon prices are fair per country compared to other countries. Risk of higher costs for companies and consumers is higher poverty, unemployment, which requires generated tax income to be partially allocated to subsidies to compensate for poverty, so less subsidies available for climate policy goals.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: easy to implement and to control, cap-and-trade is particularly interesting as it does not require the regulator is informed about firms technologies.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: I think the efficiency-improving character of the cap-and-trade has been largely overrated. I do not question it constitutes an improvement with respect to "doing nothing", but it should not be seen as the optimal mechanism regarding efficiency
further_research: Most of the theoretical studies on those mechanisms have been developed for settings that are far from real scenarios in environmental problems. Frequently, environmental economists take the "final message" of that theory, but without paying attention to the scenario under which it was developed.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Enable to shift the burden of the damage caused by CO2 emissions to the major emitters. Gives liberty to emitters to either change their sources of emission or keep paying a price for their emissions. Provide a flexible and least cost way to society. Enable international body place a price on emitting countries for their emissions.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Countries/societies might not be transparent to disclose their emissions levels. Where the impact of CO2 emissions are really felt might not receive the resultant proceed from carbon price due to political irrelevances and national instability. The advent of COVID-19 could impact strongly on nations economy, thus reducing the financial flow from carbon price
further_research: The Economic Implication of carbon price in developing countries/emerging economies. The social welfare to enhance proper utilization of Carbon price in emerging economies. The mitigation strategy to enhance proper standard for carbon price in developed countries
final_comments_cp_1: Highly relevant for a climate finance study

Research_interests_1: Equitable transition, progress business voices, business-policy cooperation, trade and climate, policy design and delivery (all sectors of the economy)
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Supports the polluter pays principle and, if appropriately applied, provides a financial incentive to change consumption patterns
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Free allocation for businesses creates perverse incentives if not amended radically. Carbon tax for buildings and transport can have severe adverse distributional impacts and limited effectiveness, because the price that would be high enough to incentivize behavior change among households who have the financial resources to make choices is prohibitively high for low-income households who, by and large, lack the financial resources to change their consumption patterns in response to the increasing costs (and the ability to make decisions over e.g. their heating fuel use in rented properties)
further_research: Sector-specific approaches. E.g. the removal of free allowances under the ETS is necessary, however, is it appropriate to treat all sectors that are covered by the ETS the same way? There are big differences in the currently available decarbonization technologies available for steel and cement, for example. Also carbon pricing applied to heating fuels and private car use would need to be means-tested to avoid adverse distributional impacts (and thus risk losing public support for ambitious climate policy) - this is a question that hasn't really been looked at. ie. how could carbon pricing be delivered in a way that is more fair than the current plans deliver (e.g. the obvious shortcomings of the EU Social Climate Fund).

comments_background_1: I believe that "economic growth" is necessary, but this can be in qualitative terms. Having more leisure (with a constant production) also counts as growth.  Consuming fewer (but more expensive) goods also is consistent with growth. Naturally, we cannot have endless growth in terms of materials use, given a limited materials supply, but this is not what economists mean when they argue for growth.

criteria_5_SP: ability to see tangible results traced to the policy
comments_1: It is also important to think about more links between policy design and implementation
comments_policy_rank_1: I think one of the key issues is that some of the instruments that are favored for certain reasons (such as efficiency) neglect the implications in other dimensions (such as equity and feasibility depending on the context).
important_policies_7_SP: overall strategy, vision that involves the public
comments_important_policies_1: I think taking a systemic  / comprehensive / coherent approach is most important.  For instance, having a government that signals that climate policy is an important goal for them and said government putting the mechanisms in place (personnel, resources, etc.) to make sure they are able to follow through.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: I think a key strength is to do with efficiency (it is administratively less burdensome) and clarity (people can - ideally - see specifically how much is being paid).  Another aspect that seems to be useful is when people can see what the benefits are (either in the general coffers or allocated to specific areas such as reducing health pollution which can also reduce greenhouse gas emissions)
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: From an equity perspective, it can be polarizing.  For instance, rural places are often more reliant on road transportation options that are heavily reliant on fossil fuels (as opposed to cities where biking, walking and public transit may be more feasible) and so a carbon tax can pit urban vs. rural dwellers against each other.
comments_cp_statements1_1: As noted above, I think a carbon tax can be useful but not on its own - rather I think it would be better if it were one component in a government's toolbox.  Also, I think that equity considerations must be at the forefront (see note earlier about exacerbating the urban / rural divide.  And, I should add suburban as a lot of the population in North America live in car-dependent neighborhoods in the urban periphery.
comments_2nd_order_1: Economists tend to favor a carbon tax.  It's the non economists that argue for a more systemic approach.
further_research: I think the equity dimension is important.  Also, I've seen studies that talk about benefits with some arguing about the need to tailor the benefits to specific concrete things such as reducing air pollution, while other studies note that as long as funds go to general government coffers people seem to be okay with that too (so does this depend on the context?)  It would also be useful to see the extent to which a carbon tax on its own or as a suite of measures aimed at climate mitigation (and with other co benefits such as reducing air pollution) can be more effective (in terms of reducing emissions and increasing or maintaining social acceptance and doing so more equitably).

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon tax would have been great 20 years ago. Now it is not necessary, since clear technology will now decarbonize the global economy naturally. Carbon tax can rectify some inequities, if executed well.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon tax is no longer necessary, it will cost enormous political capital which means sacrificing other social progress, and it could easily be corrupted and fail to reduce inequities. In some countries it is also very politically divisive.
further_research: Most scholars in the environmental disciplines completely fail to understand technology. As a result, they do not realize how quickly decarbonization will occur through markets. They therefore focus on carbon pricing and tax based on the false assumption that we will be stuck with today's technologies for decades. The exponential growth of renewables and EVs and the collapse of coal are clear signs that fossil fuels are on the brink of collapse. Carbon pricing and tax will seem ridiculous by 2035.

Research_interests_1: Natural climate solutions, technological climate mitigation
comments_1: Essential to protect and increase  CO2 accumulation out of the atmosphere while reducing emissions through efficiency, zero carbon technology and land and forest degradation
efficiency_7_SP: Protecting existing forests and other ecosystems is lowest cost option
comments_policy_rank_1: Virtually no one likes taxes. Remove subsidies for fossil fuels, deforestation and land degradation and provide subsidies instead to effective technologies and ecosystem protection, restoration and enhancement is an effective strategy.
comments_important_policies_1: Protecting and restoring ecological systems and biodiversity are essential to addressing climate.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Raising the cost of “Bads” will reduce their use. If combined with an equitable return of the collected tax to those who paid it makes it more acceptable.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: No one likes to pay more! Cap and trade is more efficient economically, but is subject to gaming the system.
comments_cp_statements1_1: Using revenues for other purposes is unpopular and subject to special interest diversion from society’s goals. Returning the fees to payers in an income progressive pattern reduces that concern as shown in the Canadian Provence of British Columbia.
comments_2nd_order_1: There are few examples where carbon taxes have not met with strong pushback.  Systematic, comprehensive social science research should inform any decisions.
further_research: There is a dearth of studies that test the acceptability of carbon pricing. There are many examples of negative reactions. People clearly prefer incentives  to  “tax penalties.” A combination of taxes and penalties might be more acceptable. Tax and rebate where tried has proven popular to business and the public.
comments_background_1: Right and left are inadequate for defining one’s social views. Alternatives are selfish and sharing, or individual benefit and societal benefit. There are both social and economic dimensions, and individuals may be fiscally conservative but socially liberal.
final_comments_cp_1: The survey appears to be “pushing” economic strategies to address climate change. These are important, and can be used if they take into account public preferences.  People prefer a combination of subsidies and other incentives to taxes and punishment. Regulations have proven effective in everything ferromagnetic seat belts and airbags to. Vehicle and stationary air emissions. It is notable that the costs of all these devices have dropped significantly once they were mandated.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: economic incentive, Implementation
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Political support

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: A carbon tax coupled with rebates to low-income people would have a significant effect on behavior, probably reducing use of fossil fuels considerably.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: There is little to no prospect for adoption of carbon taxes or a cap-and-trade system on the global level and with sufficient economic impact to matter.
comments_2nd_order_1: Most political scientists focus on other topics.
further_research: Advocates of carbon pricing need to be aware of the formidable barriers to this solution to the emissions problem, such as the power of oil companies in the political process.
final_comments_cp_1: Imposing carbon taxes at this point might be a bit late. The world is already on track for at least 1.5C temperature rise, the target threshold of Paris, no matter what we do. Given the lack of progress on reducing GHG emissions, 2C is all but certain, and we could be headed toward 4C by the end of the century. The question is whether the world can adapt in any equitable, effective way to a much warmer world. This question will be central after a carbon tax is no longer relevant.

criteria_5_SP: Ethical considerations other than distributional fairness
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Political feasibility: if we get robust mitigation, pricing might be what gets us there. Universal scope
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: I do not think it is likely to be as fair or as liberty-preserving as it is often thought to be; progressive pricing (which is perfectly realistic) need not equate with fair pricing
further_research: I would like to have (more) empirical evidence on the following scenario: a progessive carbon price plus refund scheme makes it the case that not very affluent people can emit as much as before and still gain money, yet would gain even more money if they emitted less. Will they act according to the incentive or not?

weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: when certain sectors are exempted from the carbon pricing (e.g. waste incineration of MSW which is continues to be exempted under the current revision of the EU Waste Directive), it sends the wrong signal to the market and hinders the market entry/deployment of alternative technologies which are - under existing regulatory framework where mature industries have optimized their operations - not yet economically competitive

Research_interests_1: Energy politics, environmental assessment, Indigenous rights
comments_1: Feasibility changes completely if you include political support for, or opposition to, proposed measures. In Canada the oil and gas industry has strong lobbying power, which could render even mild climate plans 'infeasible' the way you define the term here. 'Is it possible?' is a completely different question from, 'will politically powerful actors like it?'
effectiveness_7_SP: Divestment from fossil fuel industry; elimination of subsidies for fossil fuels
efficiency_7_SP: Divestment and ending fossil fuel subsidies
equity_7_SP: Divestment and removal of fossil fuel subsidies
feasible_7_SP: Divestment and removal of fossil fuel subsidies
comments_policy_rank_1: Again, I don't know how to answer about feasibility defined this way.
important_policies_7_SP: Divestment and removal of fossil fuel subsidies
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: These measures are relatively simple to implement and clear to communicate. They function in ways that people already understand (like a tax). There is enough evidence that they don't cause society to collapse that even economically conservative governments should feel comfortable adopting them.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: As I understand it, cap and trade doesn't significantly reduce emissions, it just concentrates the "right to pollute" on larger businesses that can afford to pay a bit extra. Carbon tax has the potential to be redistributive, but equity gains are not guaranteed - it depends on the terms of how it's implemented.
comments_2nd_order_1: Is my primary field geographers who study energy justice issues, like me? Or geographers generally, including physical geographers who work on the geology of petroleum reserves?
further_research: Equity effects
final_comments_cp_1: Answering thoughtfully took more than 10 minutes. I am curious why the detailed questions were only about carbon pricing and not the other measures listed.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Efficiency - it puts a cost on carbon and let’s the market use that information.

comments_1: There needs to be a stronger focus on cultural impacts, not just as a subtext to economic concerns.
comments_policy_rank_1: In local communities and Indigenous territories all of these are lacking. They do not incorporate them in the decision making processes or utilize local and indigenous expertise and knowledges in developing more sustainable solutions.
comments_important_policies_1: The carbon tax would be great if it were high enough to matter to million dollar corporations. Cap and trade could possibly work with a complete overhaul in its application. First, fossil fuel subsidies need to be completely removed, then apply these programs.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Having these programs makes people somewhat aware of the fact that carbon emissions are an issue.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The price is too low for carbon. It therefore provides no deterrent. Tax is a good idea in theory, but companies pass on price increase to consumers. Cap and trade just shifts the burden to others. There should be an overall limit to how much carbon emissions each company can produce, which should be incremental perhaps, but preferably cut significantly by 2030 at the absolute latest. We need complete elimination of all subsidies to polluting companies, high (legal) penalties for those who exceed their limit (not financial ones that can be passed to consumers).
further_research: I know about carbon pricing because I am friends with scholars who study it, and it is within my specific realm of study. To others the ripple effects are not known , and the mechanisms are not clear as to how it works. It obviously is not effective because companies still pollute excessive amounts of carbon, consumers are not knowledgeable enough to demand the change needed, and our temps and CO2 ppm are still rising decades after this type of mechanism was put in place.
final_comments_cp_1: It is a good survey to have and hopefully it reaches many people.

comments_1: I see political feasibility as paramount, as otherwise optimal plans are useless if they remain on the drawing board. The two key political barriers appear to be economic interests and, even more problematic, partisan polarization.
comments_policy_rank_1: CDR-related geoengineering projects (e.g., direct air capture technology) appear to elicit less political pushback, and may (at least) help buy time for more comprehensive mitigation efforts.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing is important insofar as it can recapture the negative externality associated with emissions. It can be equitable (or not) depending on how the tax rate is set (or how permits are allocated or auctioned), and how revenues are distributed.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing is problematic in that there are widely divergent models of how to derive the social cost of carbon. It also faces severe political obstacles, at least in the U.S. Internationally, C&T is problematic insofar as there's no standardized global system of carbon accounting.
comments_cp_statements1_1: A catch-22 about carbon taxes (re: point J) is that although it generates public revenues, those revenues will reduce to near zero over time if the policy is effective at reducing emissions—so neither taxpayers nor policymakers should rely on that revenue stream as a substitute for others.
comments_2nd_order_1: Tricky question because colleagues in my field don't necessarily focus on environmental issues. Of those who do, I'd estimate 50-75% would agree.
further_research: How might it be possible to frame the issue politically so as to emphasize the benefits, rather than just the costs?
comments_background_1: Being far to the left politically in the U.S. is not, actually, as far to the left as it would be in many other countries.
final_comments_cp_1: Well-structured and clear.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: The primary strength of carbon pricing comes from its efficiency. Another strength of carbon pricing can be the flexibility in its design. For example, appropriate design of  a carbon tax or cap-and-trade can turn a regressive policy progressive. A final strength particularly for cap-and-trade is the certainty in quantitative targets. With a carbon tax, there is uncertainty in the resulting emissions levels. However, with cap-and-trade, the policy can ensure quantity targets are in line with the latest scientific suggestions.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The primary weakness of carbon pricing is its feasibility. Whatever the reason, there can be strong political distaste for carbon pricing policies. This is particularly true for carbon taxes. Another weakness with respect to certain other instruments is leakage risk.
further_research: How to overcome political infeasibility.

comments_1: We play too much at the margins worrying about efficiency. It is important to take cost-effective action, but I am happy with the Second Best (or Third Best, or Fourth Best) policy if it is effective and will be politically acceptable and durable. (Invoking the Theory of the Second Best)
comments_policy_rank_1: For the equity criterion we would need to know the design of each; good design can ameliorate equity issues. For example carbon pricing becomes progressive when revenues are used for per-capita dividend payments.
comments_important_policies_1: Information is very important to communicate the issue and the need to drive emissions to zero. But, it has little effect on emissions. So, some of these are necessary, but not sufficient policies
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: We know that carbon pricing offers the 'least-cost' means of reducing GHG emissions. This paper by Baranzini et al elaborates the strengths of carbon pricing well: DOI: 10.1002/wcc.462.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: In North America we have poisoned the well on taxation. As Alex Himelfarb has written "tax is not a four-letter word", but taxation is demonized. This makes it easy for carbon pricing to be used as a wedge issue in elections. Mark Jaccard has outlined how the Canadian Conservative Party successfully used carbon pricing as a wedge issue to win elections in Canada. See Mark's book 'A Citizen's Guide to Climate Success' Chapter 6 "We Must Price Carbon Emissions": https://doi.org/10.1017/9781108783453.
comments_cp_statements1_1: Sector-specific policies can be more effective than carbon pricing depending on stringency. In Canada we used regulation to phase out coal power plants. Carbon pricing is complementing this policy by incentivizing utilities to run existing coal plants less. Zero-emissions vehicle (ZEV) mandates can drive electric vehicle adoption at a fast rate without inducing the public backlash that high gas prices tend to create in North America.
comments_2nd_order_1: There will be some who view the political economy of carbon pricing as problematic.
further_research: When does regulation provide the 'optimal' approach to emissions reduction? Carbon pricing drives innovation, but when a cost-effective innovation exists in a sector (e.g. electric vehicles), regulation can step in to require aggressive adoption. Of course, high carbon prices would do the same, but regulation sort of sweeps up the crumbs of laggards and slow adopters.
comments_background_1: Like many who consider themselves 'Green' I would encourage a move away from left-right binary thinking. I think it is too simplistic and creates unnecessary division. I'm a climate 'hawk'; I want to see actions that drive emissions down to zero quickly. That is the basis of my politics.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon pricing is the first-best economic policy. It should thus be the main focus of policy, and other policies should be considered only if there are additional market failures such as information asymmetries, principal-agent problems, market power, etc.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: The main problem with carbon pricing has been fairness (equity). The income-regressivity of carbon pricing can be fully compensated through revenue-neutral "carbon dividend" rebates to households in a per-capita fashion. Most low-income households will gain from such a policy.

further_research: The effect of carbon pricing on equity remains an active research area as to date there have been few carbon pricing schemes with high prices to make a significant distributive impact.

comments_1: Climate policy instruments currently are based on the hypothesis that global warming is caused by anthropogenic carbon dioxide. I have shown that global warming is the result of natural climate cycles. Therefore, policies are unnecessary and futile.
comments_policy_rank_1: None of these categories is relevant to climate policy because climate change is natural, not caused by humans.
comments_important_policies_1: These questions are not relevant to climate policy because climate change is natural, not anthropogenic.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Regulation of CO2 is critical because of ocean acidification. carbon tax is direct economic incentive and is essential.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: People will object and therefore have to be educated. However, correct education is impossible currently because of the pervasive incorrect belief that CO2 is the cause of warming.
comments_cp_statements1_1: Again, these questions are answered in the context that CO2 causes ocean acidification and should therefore be limited, but not global warming, which is natural in origin.
further_research: Purpose. It is to preclude ocean acidification and biodiversity protection, not climate change.
comments_background_1: Regulation of carbon dioxide is essential to prevent biodiversity extinction. It is not a solution to climate change because climate change is driven primarily by natural forces.
final_comments_cp_1: It assumes, incorrectly, that atmospheric carbon dioxide is the cause of the current global warming episode. In fact, current global warming is caused by natural climate cycles that arise in Antarctica and propagate to the rest of the globe. It is futile to even attempt to oppose such powerful natural forces. Adaptation is the only solution. In contrast, regulation of carbon dioxide is essential to protecting biodiversity.

comments_policy_rank_1: Some of the answers could vary substantially depending on the details of the policy. There are many different ways cap & trade can be implemented, which could (e.g.) be better or worse for equity.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: For better or worse, the world functions under a broadly capitalist system. A carbon price fits in well with this system, and probably will reduce emissions to some extent, at least if it is reasonably well implemented.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Two main weaknesses. The first is that a carbon price can easily exacerbate inequalities, because any costs are often passed onto consumers. These additional costs have disproportional effects on the poor compared with the rich. Rebates from the tax collected can mitigate this to some extent, but it's not clear how well this will actually work. The second (and perhaps bigger) problem is that it becomes far too easy for decision-makers in capitalist systems to assume that a carbon price is all that's needed to address climate change. It is highly likely other policies will be required, but too much attention gets paid to the carbon price. Eventually (at least according to economists models) a carbon price set at the correct level will reduce emissions to the required level. However, there is no guarantee this will happen quickly enough, given the complex social and technical transitions that are required.
further_research: Empirical, real world studies on how rebates can reduce inequalities

Research_interests_1: climate sensitivity, climate change attribution, emissions metrics
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Cap and trade allows people who can abate at low cost sell these options to people who can't. It tends to be more efficient because some players can monetise their abatement potential. More generally, direct pricing puts the same price on all CO2, and in doing so avoids the lumpiness, inefficiency and inequality that goes along with direct regulation. We know that direct regulation is less efficient than carbon pricing from simple economic considerations.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: We also know from experience that some sectors are more politically able to resist direct regulation than others - thus regulatory approaches tend to exempt certain sectors and affect others. This creates equity issues. Related to these, adoption subsidies have a tendency towards middle-class capture - comparatively wealthy people argue for these, and benefit from them. Again this exacerbates inequalities.
comments_2nd_order_1: Perhaps I am optimistic regarding my colleagues' economic literacy, but I would hope more than half of my physical science colleagues would accept this.
further_research: I don't think we know much about high carbon prices. Halting warming requires net zero CO2 emissions, and the work by Vernon Smith (1973) established that you pretty much need a high and steeply rising price on a stock pollutant to stop its release. It seems to me that the only thing that can limit the growth of that price is technology, which can find substitutes as the price on the pollutant gets higher. In the real world, though, the other lever than can halt the rise of that price is politics, as fossil revanchists make the case that (1) the price is too high in view of (2) the fact that competitors have nowhere near as high a price. It seems to me that low carbon tech is in a race with that political effect. And I'm not sure we know very much about the factors that will determine the outcome.
comments_background_1: I think the political spectrum question is probably very relative to one's own political context. I am a swing voter in NZ and was also a swing voter in the UK. In most parts of the US I expect I would be a Democrat. I think I would probably vote CSU/CDU in Germany, and would be a Labor voter in Australia and a swing voter in Canada.
final_comments_cp_1: Since about 2010 I think economic illiteracy has been a bigger problem for climate change than climate science denial.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Can reflect social cost of carbon (SCC). Least-cost, economics favored approach. Can be differentiated to account for heterogeneity in SCC or in abatement costs/equity

If carbon pricing is tied to meeting exogenous mitigation goals that are not driven by an economic optimization, then the main knowledge gap is understanding abatement costs and effects of future uncertainty on abatement levels and resulting goal attainment.

criteria_5_SP: Avoiding rebound effects and other adverse secondary effects (part of efficiency)
comments_policy_rank_1: Your definition of effectiveness and efficiency is non-standard to economics to my knowledge. Standard in econ is: Effectiveness = achieving fixed objective at lowest cost. Efficiency = Get an efficient (low-cost) objective by first comparing costs and benefits and then achieve it at lowest cost. I ANSWERED THE QUESTION ON THE PREVIOUS PAGE ACCORDING TO THIS STANDARD ECON DEFINITION. NOW I CANNOT RETURN. IF OTHER ECONOMISTS DO THE SAME, ALL OF YOUR RESULTS MAY BE BIASED FOR ECONOMISTS IN YOUR SAMPLE.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: A tax achieves emissions reductions at *lowest possible costs* to society because it equalizes marginal costs. This also holds for cap-and-trade, but a tax is much *easier* to understand for decision makers. Cap-and-trade can lead to the problem of being too complicated and as a result, implementations can become ineffective  (see research on counterintuitive effects of the market stability reserve of the EU ETS). Taxes are in principle straightforward to implement.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Will have regressive impact on households and therefore, must be accompanied by EFFICIENT measures to counteract the burden on low-income households. As for most climate policy measures, carbon leakage must be dealt with. Taxes are sometimes difficult for policy makers to advocate because of public support issues for taxes in general.
further_research: Most of it is on the table.
final_comments_cp_1: Please reconsider the definitions of effectiveness and efficiency used. I know them different than described and therefore, my answer to the first question using those definitions may be biased. I thought, it is standard to economics that effectiveness means achieving a given objective at lowest cost, while efficiency means to determine that objective given costs and benefits.

Research_interests_1: scenarios, consumption, wellbeing, sustainability, energy, transport, economy, transition, transformation, public policy
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Simplicity and scope
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Both actual real-world policy evidence and cutting edge modelling shows it is. -not sufficient alone. -a distraction from fundamental measures required for systems transition and reaching win-win outcomes. -not feasible at rates required. -frequently not the most economically efficient approach (e.g. transport and built environment) as per IPCC
comments_2nd_order_1: Carbon pricing is useful,  but also shows dogmatic ideological tendencies. These are based on weakly defended theory rather than on evidence. There is an excessive dominance of 'climate capitalism' that leads to this interpretation, and it is not sufficiently questioned by many researchers. The focus on carbon pricing reflects more a fashionable practice in political economy rather than a well-supported theory on how to reduce emissions in line with deep reductions and achieving win-wins. This requires systems change, in which the market and pricing must be guided by appropriate policy intervention, including regulation and changes to systems and practices.
further_research: Transformation and transition requires systems changes, this is established in the literature. Carbon pricing is only a supporting measures, and that is primarily to prevent rebounds and generate revenue. Research on carbon pricing needs to focus on how it can assist the wider systems change policy portfolios, including regulation, standards, and sustainable development strategies for systems, that are required for near-zero and sustainable outcomes to be feasible.

Research_interests_1: carbon taxes, distributional effects of environmental taxes
comments_policy_rank_1: Both the equity and feasibility of economic instruments, such as carbon tax and cap-and-trade, depend on the country where it is implemented. Carbon taxes will be more regressive in the US than in, for instance, Denmark and Sweden. Similarly, economic instruments are politically more feasible in Denmark and Sweden than in the US or Australia.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Increased prices reduce demand. In that way, I believe carbon pricing to be effective in reducing emissions. Once in place, I also believe it is rather easy to increase the rate of the carbon price and that businesses and consumers will adapt over time -- making it easier politically to keep the tax in place.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: May not be politically feasible to implement in some countries, such as the US, for whatever reason. In that context, subsidies or other forms of support for renewable energy and electric vehicles may be a more effective climate policy approach.
further_research: That revenue-recycling may not make every household in the lower deciles of the income distribution better off. There is large heterogeneity when it comes to, for instance, transport fuel consumption in the bottom half of the income distribution. I believe that many low-income households (rightly) assume that while their decile may be better off on average -- from a carbon tax with revenue-recycling scheme -- that is not necessarily true for them (considering their higher-than-average consumption of fossil fuels).
final_comments_cp_1: Nice survey!

Research_interests_1: climate policy, energy systems, techno-economic modeling, electricity markets
comments_1: Exploring the solution space for “near-optimal” solutions and multi-criteria decision making are important directions for the field.
comments_policy_rank_1: Much of this will depend on how each instrument is designed. My answers are based on how these instruments have tended to be designed.
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Efficiency (the greater its role in the mix, the lower the total $/tCO2 cost of the overall policy mix), scope (ability to cover multiple sectors), equity (can be progressive depending on the design)
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Low political feasibility, risk (relative to instruments like FiT and long-term contracting, carbon pricing gives investors in low-carbon technologies limited guarantee of future returns, especially for cap-and-trade with its volatile carbon prices but also for carbon taxes, since investors will still face other risks stemming from e.g. volatile electricity prices. This is a problem to the extent that investors cannot hedge risks due to missing markets), limited impact on innovation and learning (technologies generally benefit from technology push to make it through commercialization and progress through their learning curves), and, possibly, dynamic efficiency (a carbon price may not sufficiently incentivize markets to follow the lowest-cost pathway toward long-term goals, perhaps due to its limited effect on innovation, a topic for future research), limited ability to incentivize efficiency (there may be actions that are already economical, like home retrofits, but are not done due to bounded rationality).
comments_cp_statements1_1: With regard to h), Harmonizing carbon pricing across countries is in theory easy but in practice very difficult and arguably not in countries’ interests, in part because countries are driven to implement the policies that benefit them (e.g. the ones that deliver local co-benefits), not to allocate mitigation to where it is most efficient (the point of global carbon pricing).
further_research: To what extent are the advantages and disadvantages of carbon pricing dependent on how it is designed and to what extent are they inherent? Is the low political feasibility of pricing an inherent feature? Can we expect it to continue to be politically unpopular (a lot of the research on this is retrospective)? Is carbon pricing dynamically efficient (i.e. does it incentivize efficient long-term decisions; does it incentivize meeting long-term targets in the most cost-efficient way, especially considering technology learning effects and the existence of local optima typically not considered in most research)? How can/should carbon pricing be integrated into policy mixes (e.g. what are potential mixes that balance the distinct advantages of different instruments)?
comments_background_1: Thank you for doing this important research.
final_comments_cp_1: Thank you for doing this important research.

Research_interests_1: Politics of carbon pricing, carbon taxation, elite political capture
strengths - CP_strength_weakness: I don’t think emission trading and carbon taxes should be grouped together. Carbon taxes allow policy makers to precisely control the price on carbon, which is predictable to businesses and consumers, and they are relatively easy to implement and enforce (they build on existing fiscal institutions and are placed on goods upstream). Emission trading systems allow for more precision in the level of emissions (in theory) and often have more business support.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Carbon taxes are never designed according to economists recommendations. They always include carve outs or rebates for emitting industries, reducing their effectiveness. Emission trading systems have been poorly designed and are not clearly linked to significant emission reductions for similar reasons, as well as instances where the market price was simply too low. Their design also opens up the possibility of the possibility of market manipulation, or speculation.
further_research: Will policy makers allow carbon pricing to reduce emissions? This will necessarily mean lower revenues for the state. It might not be rational, from that perspective, to price carbon at a level that will dramatically reduce revenues rather than at a price that will optimize revenues. Also, revenue neutrality seems like a dumb idea if we expect these policies to work — the state will ultimately end up with less revenue.

strengths - CP_strength_weakness: Achieving emission reductions at lowest cost (i.e. their efficiency) and their effectiveness. Straightforward. Polluter pays.
weaknesses - CP_strength_weakness: Their political feasibility. Lack of political and public support. Misconceptions among the public about regressive impacts and inefficiency of carbon taxes.
further_research: How trust and people's perceptions of the quality of government institutions (including corruption perceptions, impartiality and government effectiveness) impact public support for carbon pricing. This may provide important insights on how public support may be increased.
final_comments_cp_1: Excellent!
